Met with my old friends to watch the NBA Finals at Pete's Tavern.  But we got there at 6ish, and it was standing room only, so my friend Decided that since she lives right there to pick up some Amici's and beers and hang out at her place (she got a 50" HD Plasma, so it's alright by me!).

Amici's made my day.  It was crowded, but the staff at the cashier table were patient, efficient, and friendly!  I ordered us a Large Amici Combo and added Sausage to the mix.  She was happy to take my order, smiled, and even said she loves my name! (my full name she read it on my CC). So, I tipped her for her friendliness...which was funny cuz my friend even said out loud "Why you gonna tip her?  It's a pick up order!"   It gave me the opportunity to say "well, she has a great smile, is friendly and even likes my full name!  Why not?" 

 Lady smiled again and 15 Minutes later I got a Delicious Pizza Devoured by the three of us....Crust was nice and thin, yet filling, and the Ingredients were top quality.  I honestly would have expected to pay 40 bucks for a pizza prepared their way, so it merited an extra star, especially considering us having to improvise our plans on the spot.  Eating that yummy pizza helped us make that final NBA blowout...I mean Game a little more entertaining for us (That and all the Red Stripe we were chugging with it).

 I'm coming back when I'm in the area again.
author: Gio G.

description:
Aahh Amici's....

Sometimes your pizza (when cooked for the right amount of time) just hits the spot...flavorful and not drenched with sauce and toppings. 

Other times, when you forget that the thin crust only take 5-10 mins to bake and you leave it in too long and the bottom of the crust gets burnt black...the taste isn't so pleasant. 

3.5 stars for food.

So why only a 2 star for the review? Because the service SUCKS when you eat in.  And it sucks bad when they are slow.  The server we got on Saturday took about 10 mins to bring us our water.  Only checked on us once.  Had major attitude problems when she did come over. Handed us the bill (or rather lightly threw the bill on the table) as if she was doing us a favor. And didn't ask us if we wanted a refill until after we asked for the bill. I have had only one decent eat in experience and that is why we will usually get take out or delivery.
author: Mary L.

description:
Three stars because your deliver to my apartment.  Three stars because you have good topping choices and you hooked up the pancetta.  

Deduct two stars out of the possible 5 stars because the first pizza I ordered, you put green peppers instead of roasted red peppers on my pizza and it ruined my masterpiece.  Also, your pizza can get kinda soggy and that blows.

I will order from you again though, because it's cheaper than Pizza Orgasmica and just as tasty.
author: Christina S.

description:
So far, this is the best pizza that I have had since moving to SF from NYC... Came in, ordered the 7" with pepperoni, fresh garlic, extra mozzarella, mushrooms and bacon... The taste was fantastic... Great ingredients... GREAT crust... 

Only downfall is it's on the expensive side. That pizza plus Dr Pepper was $15. 

For now, I have found my neighborhood pizza place... Finally...
author: Jen D.

description: Ok think crust pizza.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I'm kind of surprised to see so many clashing reviews on this place.  I truly enjoyed it, and I don't usually like thin-crust pizza.  I got the "Philly" pizza (sausage, caramelized onions, and green peppers), which tasted pretty solid.  The sauce and cheese were excellent, as was the preparation.  It was much better than the Goat, where last time practically half my pizza was toppingless.

Despite the price (-1 star), this is definitely my go-to pizza place now.
author: Adam W.

description:
Let me ask you something... when one says "vegetarian pizza PLUS pepperoni," what comes to mind? I'll tell you what doesn't come to mind... a dark black disc with some pepperoni, bell pepper and onions. Mmmmm! Taste the garden bliss!  
Overcooked, super dry, and bland. I just don't understand how you can charge 20+ for a medium pizza and feel good about yourself.

Maybe it was a one-time flop. I won't be giving them a chance for redemption...

Goat Hill for real.
author: B S.

description:
Amicis is like a saviour or close.It is conveniently located and we end up going there more often than we intend to owing to the.. yep location. The first time I came here I tried their veggie pizza and it sucked.It had some kinda weird smell emanating from it...Tossed it. Then someone organised a birthday get together here so had to go...this time around the food was much better. It was almost tasty. Then I came here the third time with friends slightly sceptical and not knowing what to expect but it turned out fine.

Service is good,food is- I can say this now tasty too. 

Well if you 're in the vicinity and cant think of any place try Amici's.
author: Natasha I.

description:
Call me a stupid West coaster, but I really like Amici's (and only at this location). That said, you have to know which pizzas to order: Boston is good, margharita (sp?) is also good, but my favorite is the White Clam pizza (with bacon and no sauce). 

Stay away from the pepperoni (too oily), Personally, I think the Amici combo has way too much meat (but I don't love a ton of meat on my pizzas). 

I agree with all the other comments about the price. Why in the world do their pizzas cost so much? 

And for the record, the best pizzas in the city: Pauline's in the Mission.
author: L. M.

description:
Delivery: cold, congealed and greasy. The delivery guy must've stopped for a smoke break on the way to my house. Delivery NOT recommended.

Dining in restaurant: Excellent, thin crust pizza (Margherita is delicious), generous antipasto salad, obliging and courteous waitress.  Definitely recommend if you're in the area (parking can be expensive as they only validate for 20 minutes).
author: Suepattra M.

description:
4 pizza delivery...
...all of the undersides were burnt.

one star removal for ME, thinking that they'd be any better the next day.
author: Ting A.

description:
service is a big deal for me, and Amici's passed the test with flying colors. The server was friendly and very helpful. My drinks did not even get to half empty before getting refilled. We didnt wait very long for anything, not the greeting, the drink order, or the food order. 

I ordered the trentino which was very good. Their menus warned of black crust which I thought was delicious. 

My only two complaints are that I thought the food was a little overpriced for what I got. we walked out of there for $40 for two tiny pizzas and two iced teas. My other complaint was the iced tea. It had some wierd flavor to it, like it was a passionfruit iced tea or something and I was not expecting that. Normally I would not complain, but it  was not a very good surprise. Not a big deal, at all. 

All that said I thought it was pretty good and I might go back during a ball game because it is right next to ATT park. Cool locale.
author: Ben H.

description:
Its funny.  I opened my salad container to be confronted with the produce section at Safeway.  Inside were many large peices of romaine, a few red onion and green pepper rings, and what I believe to be three large tomatoes, cut in half and distributed evenly throughout the outer periphery of the "salad".

Ok, well they advertise the best PIZZA west of NY, not the most ethereal salads north of LA.  So I will back off.  The pizza was flatabulous - I had the Pollo (my fav) with roasted garlic, which sent me to a level of heaven where angels dance and parmesan falls like snow.  I also had a classic spinach and black olives, which had the most incredible tomato/cream sauce, and then the veggie, with carmelized onions.  Next time I'm trying the roasted eggplant.  Delivery was super fast too.  Now that I have discovered Amici's, I guess I will have to run more.  Yay.
author: Catherine F.

description:
If I could come back in another life and be a pizza restaurant on the West Coast, I would be Amici's. Let's face it...when us East Coast transplants hop in the covered wagons and make our journey across the US, the first thing we look for after stabling our horses is a good pizza place.

So, I've made a decision. You must have your favorite category of New York pizza, a favorite Chicago Pizza, and now, a completely separate West Coast favorite. And if I am picking my favorite West Coast pizza...this is it. I mean, I have tried a lot of pizza here so far that I would probably only eat again if I were homeless, but this little gem (and you wouldn't guess that it is more of a chain than a one off) is different. It would be foolish of someone to try and compare anything to the masterpieces that come from NYC or Chicago, but it is safe to say, this place is good.

Now that the baseball season is over, you will have no problem getting in here at anytime. And if they were open at 4am, I would be embarssed to say I would have been there.
I went with a date and was sat promptly at a nice table in front of the window looking out on the main drag. We ordered a large (which is 14 inches, but seems bigger...yeah, a guy said that...but it's the truth) and it is plenty. In five minutes or less, the pizza was hot and steaming and smelling great right in front of us.

The pepperoni is fantastic. If you have tried to best places in New York and know the difference between Bella Grande pepperoni and the Wal-Mart pouch that Domino's uses, it' s a must taste.

And the best part...the brick oven. The pizzas come out with that charred, black smokey crisp, without being burnt, and still having great texture.

For those that might argue it isn't close to NYC pizza, I will remind before you walk in that NYC is 2500 miles away, and for that reason, this is as close as I can find. I might be all about the looks like all the rest of those guys, but this girl is great on the inside too. Enjoy!

Pros: quick service, nice pizza atmosphere, great outside seating, brick oven taste.

Cons: price, and the fact that I can't go pick one of a tree to eat everytime I get hungry
author: Michael G.

description:
Stopped here after 14 innings of Giants/Yankees baseball.  Lotsa people lining up of course, but needing only a table for 2, we were hooked up immediately with an inside seat.  The Yankee fans behind us ended up sitting right next to us.  They were from San Jose and were going to take Cal Train home so they asked us if we knew how often the trains run from SF.  We didn't know.  But we ended up in conversation for the most of our dinner, nice people.  

Now, you may have read some of my other reviews regarding pizza, so you should know that I am married to a person nicknamed the Pizza King.  He was in full force on Saturday.  Whatever you want, honey, I'm willing to try something different, except artichoke hearts, I really can't eat those.  And I want a large of whatever we get, we can take it home if needed.  OK I said, and started perusing the menu.  Most of the pizzas in size large were more than $20, a little pricey for the thin crust I would say.  But, we are in SF I guess we're paying for the rent, not so much for the pizza.  I suggested getting a New Yorker (mozzarella and tomato sauce) and adding hot italian sausage and jalapenos (at $1.30 each).  He agreed and thought that was a fantastic choice.  

Our server was on top of it right from the beginning, or about 7-8 minutes into our arrival--it was packed.  She asked if we wanted drinks and/or salads, we said YES and YES.  The pitchers are only $12.50 for your gourmet microbrews, we opted for the Pilsner Urquell.  I paid $9.00 for a 16 oz. Harp in the ballpark.  It hit the spot with the spicey pizza we chose. We also ordered the small Caeser to split, but she mistakenly gave us a large--that's OK she said, I'll only charge you for the small, my error.  Me likey.  

Pizza arrived within about 15 minutes and was piping hot.  Pretty tasty.  Pizza King agreed.  So did our neighboring Yankee fans.  They ended up ordering more because the medium was not enough for their two hungry selves.  They also ordered another pitcher.   The server checked in on us at appropriate times and was attentive without being annoying.  

I'd say that they get 4 stars for this experience, the prices are high that's my only complaint.  Stop by here after a game, maybe you'll see us.
author: Anne O.

description:
I have not been to the new one on Lombard, but as for its' former location, I think Amici's does a pretty good job.  The one thing that I notice is that the pizza here can be inconsistent.  Some nights it is just right, others, too greasy, or too burnt crust, or the toppings are not what they were before.  What can you say,  it's pizza.  

If I am in the mood for a really good thin crust pizza, and want the possibility of fried eggplant on it, I come here.  As for their other toppings, it is good, just not outstanding.

BTW, it does run you a little more than most places.
author: Kapeli M.

description:
Super good pizza! I had 2 tacos from TB at 4PM. By 6PM, I scarfed down 4 slices of a large pizza at Amici's... That's half of the pie! Just thinking about it now makes my mouth water.

We dined in and found the atmosphere to be quite nice. The service was friendly and we got our pizza in minutes. One star off because our pizza was a bit too burnt and the prices are a bit high, but I still think it's worth it and I'm definitely coming back!
author: Vitamin C.

description:
Just went to Amici's tonight for dinner and I was again reminded that all the things I love about New York are right here in SF.  The pizza was that wonderful combo of being thin yet crispy.  We got the pepperoni mushroom pizza and it was quite good.  Also, the minestrone soup was a strong opener as well.  I had the pesto and clam pasta that was a disappointment, because of the over-the-top-not-in-a-good-way olive oil on this dish, so minus one star.  

This place is never so busy you can't get a table right away and the decor is an improvement over the sad affair that was prevalent at the Union street location.  Also, there is usually ample parking at the cal-train station which is just a hop skip and a jump away.  Overall, the four stars is more for the pizza, I'd give the pasta 2 1/2 to 3 stars max.  I'd absolutly recommend it and look forward to our return trip.
author: Chris W J.

description: High price for low quality take-out. The $15 Double Garden Salad is just some romaine lettuce with a few strips of green pepper and red onion, with a couple halved cherry tomatoes. Apparently they haven't heard about other vegetables in the garden, like carrots, mushrooms or cucumbers. I've had better salads at Subway for half the price. As for the pizza, if you like a hard cracker crust with a hint of cheese and millimeter-thin coins of sausage, you'll be in heaven. Save your hard-earned dollars and pick up a frozen pie at nearby Safeway.
author: Lynn C.

description:
HOLY COW!  Who'd-a-thunk that Amici's Pizzeria would kick so much ass!  For all my bitchy reviews, this time, I'm gushing!

After work, the other day, we wandered into Amici's for dinner, only because it was convenient.  I got the best service that I think I've had anywhere in this city in months!

I've been a delivery customer of various Amici's locations for years and this was the first time I ate there.  

Dinner was great!  The wine was good.  The little thin crust mini pizzas were simply delicious.  And our server never missed a beat.  He swooped down to grab every crumb, straw paper, or crumpled napkin, almost before it could even hit the table.  The timing was all perfect.  Drinks never went empty.  At the end, he even brought the last two or three ounces of a $20 bottle of wine and served it up for free rather than tossing it.

I'm telling you, dinner at Amici's wasn't just surprisingly good.  It was absolutely outstanding --and my standards are pretty high!

The Bill:

* Garlic Bread Sticks
* 2 thin crust mini pizzas with goat cheese and procuitto and specialty toppings
* 1 beer
* 2 glasses of wine
--------------------------
$48

Go here!  Go here right now!  Hell, maybe I'll go back for dinner again tonight!
author: Amy A.

description: this is a good place to go to right before a Giants game but you must go early probably 2 hrs till game time if you want decent seats. During the off season this place isn't full on weekdays so that could also be good time for those who doesn't like big crowds. The pizza is good but i love their garlic bread. Always decent service, no reason to whine about anything.
author: Anne A.

description:
Pretty standard pizza, nothing special.  I am not sure what makes it "east coast" pizza.  Lots of interesting pizzas on the menu, or create your own from a selection of toppings.

Pizza is pretty greasy, relatively expensive.
author: Ben B.

description:
Very tasty thin crust pizza, high quality ingredients, nice (for a pizza place) ambiance, and a great location near where I live.  This is currently my favorite pizza in San Francisco.  Initially I didn't go here because of the bad reviews; I have no idea why other people don't like this place.  I'm picky about my pizza, and this place is as good as any pizza place I've been.

Service was friendly and attentive.  I'm definitely going back.

I've not tried delivery or any dish other than the pizza.
author: Michal T.

description:
ANTIPASTO SALAD WITH CAESAR DRESSING! 

'Nough said!  ;-)
author: Kit E.

description:
I've never overpaid so much for to go pasta.  The large order of penne with meat sauce was about $15, and I wasn't even full after the meal.  The pasta was cooked fine, and the small amount of meat was good, but I would have been better off just getting some Ragu meat sauce and some penne pasta at Safeway and creating a science experiment/cooking in our office kitchen.

There was so little sauce in the penne, that I felt like I was playing the game, Where's Waldo, except the pasta version, Where's the Meat Sauce.  At first I couldn't find the meat sauce.  When I looked at the pasta, I thought that I got the wrong order because I didn't notice the meat or much sauce.  However, after about 5 minutes of investigation and digging through the pasta, I found "Waldo" or in this case, the meat sauce towards to bottom of the pasta.  I noticed a few scattered tiny pieces of meat between a few pieces of penne pasta.  Now I know what it must have been like to be part of the California Gold Rush; it was like I hit gold; finally I found some meat sauce.

The best thing about the pasta and meat sauce was the side of Parmesan cheese. Without the generous portion of Parmesan cheese to mix in with the penne, the dish would have been fairly tasteless except the few bites that actually contained meat sauce.

If I'm going to spend $15 for pasta to go, I would expect to be full from the meal and to get most of the protein from the meat sauce and not the packet of Parmesan cheese.
author: Josh K.

description: I really want to love Amicis.  I just cant.  First off they have Ralph Barbieri as their spokesman.  I cant think of a worst sports personality to be associated with.  The guy is a total hack so that may resonate and move the pie review from a 3 to a 2 star.  The pizza is okay but would prefer Round Table, Georgios, Brunos Cucina and a handful of other in SF.  I live right above it and have only gone twice and both times it was good pie but nothing unbelievable like all of the hype it receives.  The staff is very friendly and nice but the prices are a bit high.
author: Harry E.

description:
Great Pizza, if you like the thin crust type. 
We order them at least once a week.....
IF I was rating them on their delivery pizza only, it would be a 4 Stars....

BUT....
Yesterday went there for lunch and ordered some lasagna and a half antipasto salad.

I have to say that it was disappointing. The lasagna wasn't hot inside and we had to send it back to be put back in the oven. The tomatoes in the salad were old and moldy. Quality was very bad.

But every time we do eat there, the service is always very nice. 

Just make sure when you order lasagna, make sure it is nice and piping hot!
author: Christine S.

description:
*reviewer's note: Ive never been to new york, and im pretty sure I've never had authentic NY Pizza.  Im sure its delicious.

Very good pizza.  Better than any chain pizza (yeah like thats hard to beat) and deliveries always show up quickly and piping hot.  Love the thin crust, although i think their pizza menu is wierd and i always have to end up picking my own toppings which is more expensive than going with their made up selections.   2nd best pizza place i've been to behind Punch in Minnesota.
author: Cathleya G.

description:
For it being new york style pizza, it really wasn't as good as the pizza i've had in new york.  i mean it was ok, but didn't  blow me away or anything.  but the place is nice for a pizza joint.  service was very nice and surprisingly fast for it being busy.  
As for the pizza it was thin crust and almost chewy in the middle.  i'd try it again, just not anytime soon.  but it is a cool place to go before the giants game, quick meal and some beer.
author: Lester A.

description:
After listening to KNBR talk show host, Ralph Barbieri, go on and on and on about Amici's this and Amici's that I'll have to admit that I was a little intrigued because I luv a good pizza pie. And not knowing much about East Coast Pizza, I thought that was going to be a good thing.

Well, one day on the way, early to the Pac Bell Park to watch a Giant's game we passed by what was a NEW Amici's going up for business. I think it was the first week even. So, I said, "Let's go in and give it a try, I've HEARD great things about it."

So we did.

There were a lot of pizzas on the menu and the servers (all new apparently, and a lot of them too) were very nice. I don't remember there being any free pre-meal bread but they had a lot of parmesan cheese available. Did I have a salad? I might have but don't really remember.

We ordered, of course, a pizza, a healthy veggie pizza and when it came we were shocked. "is that all the pizza?", I thought. It was much smaller than I thought it would be. And when I tasted it it was all burned on the bottom, apparently from the brick pizza oven. It had no flavor except burned flavor and that's not a good flavor.

Well, the view was nice but the pizza was not. I probably should have sent the thing back but I chickened out and ate what I could anyways because it was getting close to gametime. Needless to say, I wasn't happy. Plus, it was as thin as a piece of paper, no bulk to it at all. If that is East Coast pizza, guess what East Coast, you lose. We want thick pizza out here fellas.

Maybe I just had a bad day and maybe Amici's is not for me. They certainly are doing well with all of the stores they are opening up around the Bay Area but for me, I won't be back. There are just so many better pizza options around here, like Round Table that it just isn't worth my time to give Amici's another go. Sorry.
author: Terry H.

description:
Good service and tables outside make for a nice lunch near the ballpark.  

Just another Amici's, so the food is good not great.  Best to stick with the pizza.
author: Tom K.

description: I have wanted to try this pizza ever since I went to New York and fell in love with real New York style pizza. I hear the guys on KNBR talk about how great this pizza is, so I just had to try it. What a disappointment!  The pizza was NOT even close to what we had in New York, but the beer was cold, so that helped a bit. The worst part was that the waiter was rude!  I am always extra nice to servers because I know it is a tough job, but this guy was not nice at all. He knocked into another server who was helping him and caused her to spill water all over my friend. He acted like it was her fault. It certainly wasn't!  He is bringing this place down with his attitude that he was really not happy to be there. Not a good experience and very expensive. I hate when I highly anticipate something and it's a total let down. I gave it two stars because of the good location and the fact that you can watch the guy toss pizza dough in the air as he hand throws the crust. KNBR did me wrong!  I can't believe they recommend this place. Overpriced and they need to hire much nicer waiters. Customer service can make, or break a place.
author: Carol S.

description:
Amici's in the past has reminded me of the typical strip mall place.  Normally, just good enough.  However - as of late I find myself going to the King Street location more often.  The recipe is good, but I really have noticed how well the staff work under pressure.  They get crowds seated and the kitchen really cranks out the food.  I went Friday night and it was apparent they were caught of guard by too many people coming through the door-working together, everyone got seated and served in record time.  I was really impressed by the unsung heroes in the kitchen cranking out the food.  (I was seated at the counter). 

The food - well it's not going to make the Michelin guide BUT it's fresh, tasty and affordable.  Sometimes in this life - that's all you need.
author: Dean F.

description:
Go here when you want to spend $15 for lunch, only have water and walk away hungry

Went to Borders next door to get a programming book, but was hungry and found it as an excuse to check this place out
They don't sell by the slice (so they can charge u more)

Got 10" personal pizza for $12.75?, there was a 7" but server said that was for kids and a 10" was for a big man (hmm, maybe i should have read into this more...)

Didn't want to drop extra coin for solo lunch, was even thinking about pedaling home for lunch and heating up my own safeway bought pie for $5

In my in-decisiveness, the waiter came back over and since I had already sat, had to order, got the basic NY style tomato sauce/chz

Pizza itself was good, tasty and gourmet-ish, but pricey
Kinda reminds be of Goodfellas in Staten Island NY or even the touristy Patsy Grimaldis (google the naming wars) under the Brooklyn Brigdes
Crispy crush and perhaps? fresh mozzerella

WIth the ice water, came to $15 with tip, and that was just slighty over 15%, but was already spending too much $ for a small snack

Parking? well that's a tough one, not even sure how, the embarcadero is no parking, there are some garages in the skyscrapers there, on the backside

Delivery, there is a vague blurb on their menu about free delivery with min, so I ask the min, they say $25 for some places, $30 for others
I asked what is the map, she says we dont have one, give her my address, she says $25

Also check Goat Hill in Soma or Potrero, as Well as Bowzers on 11th and Even Extreme Pizza for click thru delivery

Bottom line, if you have some $ to burn and want gourmet pizza, this place should do
author: G K.

description:
I had a mini thin-crust Pollo pizza, which was just barely big enough for lunch.  It comes without tomato sauce, which was fine with me.  Flavor was ok (I added red pepper flakes and parmesean from the table), but the crust was great.  They have a disclaimer on their menu about having dark crusts because of their ovens, but ours were light brown.  My fiance got the Pesto with hot Italian sausage and was happy with his.  

Service was meh.  The girl's voice was pleasant but her face seemed pretty unhappy.

They have a nice variety of toppings and a pretty big non-pizza menu to cater to any taste.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Calling Amici's an "East Coast Pizzeria" is a complete misnomer, as there are two styles of pizza typically found on the East Coast. First off, you have New York pizza, typified by a thin crust that is foldable which is topped with a rich combination of tomato sauce and cheese. This can be found at Arinell, not Amici's. Amici's is trying to replicate, with some success, the pizza from New Haven, Connecticut.

When it comes to New Haven style pizza, there are some significant characteristics: the crust should be very thin, seasoned with olive oil and salt and should never get floppy. This base can be covered with chopped clams, olive oil and grated cheese or it can be covered with a little red sauce, mozzarella and some toppings. Not a mountain of toppings, but some sausage, pepperoni, peppers, onions, anchovies and other bits to enhance the flavor of the pizza. Shape isn't as important, nor is cutting it into symmetrical wedges... but color is, as the bottom should have areas of jet black char from the heat of the wood or coal fired brick oven, and the top of the pizza should blister from the heat anywhere where it is not covered with cheese. Is your mouth watering yet?

Amici's tries to replicate this, and in some ways they have: the cheese mix is pretty dead on, and the crust exhibits the sort of charring and blistering you would expect, though it isn't oiled and salted first, which makes it lose out a little on the flavor. For the past few months, I usually have Amici's delivered three times a month - and the pies are consistantly good, but nowhere as good as when you get it served hot at the restaurant.

Points off for their prices, the occasional delivery issue (getting a pie with the cheese all slid over to one side), and the piece of metal my wife unfortunately found in her chicken pesto pasta one time.
author: Avery G.

description:
Too expensive for what you get. I took a star off for price alone. Helllloooooo 15 bucks for a small pizza that isn't even that great? And don't be mislead by the website as we were if ordering takeout or delivery- my man and I got 2 small pizzas, thinking we were getting the $10 ones (mini= personal) and breadsticks (Soooooo not worth it) and it was almost $50 for takeout pizza for two?!

Aside from the price, the pizza was ok, and it was ready quickly, so that's at least good. Plus there are a lot of options for toppings. But the cheese and sauce weren't anything special. I've had better frozen pizzas.

I guess the b*tch of it is, if you live in SOMA and want quick food/places close by, you are going to overpay. As my guy said, "I can barely enjoy this because I keep thinking how ripped off I was..."
author: Kristen L.

description:
Food: I had the minestrone soup and breadsticks.  The soup was pretty standard, a little small.  The breadsticks, however were amazingly delicious.  They were flaky on the outside and very soft on the inside.  Some of the best breadsticks I've ever had.

Service: The wait staff was very friendly and quick and laid back.  The place itself is well kept, spacious and laid back.

Price: The breadsticks were very dollar but the soup was over priced.  For $4 you get maybe 6 ounces of soup.
author: Mack D.

description: I have a really hard time understanding why it's always so crowded here.  Is it really worth the wait?  Not in my opinion.  Is it worth the price? Not too sure it is.
author: Britt B.

description:
Great food, friendly staff, good location.  I love thin crust pizza and they do it right.

I avoid pre-game times as they can get crowded being across from AT&T Park.   Open until 10pm most nights so good for when I am off work late.

Great place for a diet?  You bet.   Side spinach salad, no pine nuts, dressing on the side (use less than a tsp): ~165 calories.  Mini (7") extra thin pizza with onions: ~300 calories.  My numbers not theirs, I took it to-go, separated the ingredients and measured/weighed it myself (being a small chain they don't have this info).
author: Jay K.

description: Great if your going to the Ball Park for a game as it works well for groups. It's hard to find good thin crust NY style pizza especially in the area the only draw back is the price...ouch.
author: Shirley P.

description:
If you been to one Amici's you've been to them all.  That's to say that the quality of food and service is consistent throughout the Amici chain.

We were heading to AT&T Park for a night game and called ahead to Amici's for a carryout order.  When we arrived, within 15 mins, the pizza was ready.  A nice alternative to ballpark food.  They also offer a ballgame special:  $4.00 for two slices or cheese or pepperoni.  Great deal!
author: Rich W.

description:
Bf and I were walking around / apartment hunting in SOMA and I was famished after a long day. It was both our first time at Amici's and it didn't disappoint. The host and wait staff were very attentive, seated us promptly and immediately gave us our drinks. I ordered the Linguine in White Clam sauce -- very richly flavored -- and he ordered the Greek pizza (with added chicken). The clam sauce was pretty good but I wouldn't say out of this world good. The Greek pizza with feta cheese, artichokes and sundried tomatoes was superb though! I've always had a love affair with anything Greek, so I really liked that their pizza turned out great. Overall, good food at good prices! Haven't been back in some time but they had sidewalk seating the last time I went there. Always a plus for me. 

PS - If you MUST drive, park at Safeway, get something there and have them validate your ticket, then just walk down the block to this place. Oh yeah, it CAN get really crowded when the Giants are playing home games.
author: Erika I.

description:
Amici's, I heart you.  

After all these years, no matter what I'm up to, I can always count on you for a reasonably priced garden salad with amazing caesar dressing.   This can be my lunch until the end of time.

I think you heart me back, too.
author: Lorin Y.

description:
As far as pizzas go this ain't bad.  But I just can't get over paying $30 including tax for a large, that isn't even really very large.  And I don't mind paying lots for good wine or fancy food, so shoot me, I'm a hypocrite.  But pizza just feels like it should be... democratic.  And therefore reasonable.

The service is good though.  And on the rare occasion they screw up a takeout order, they're generous with the comp pizza coupons.
author: Vikram K.

description:
I was in town for the Nike Women's Marathon and needed to carbo load the night before this place definately helped me do so!!!

I was able to walk in with a party of 4 and we were seated right away.  We all shared a large pizza and large plate of spaghetti.  It was enough for the 4 of us to get our carbs!  The food was delicious! =o)  It came out hot and quickly.  It is also fairly priced.

As if the night before wasn't enough, but we went back for lunch after the marathon!  This time we split a pizza and salad, which were both very yummy.  Once again, we didn't have to wait and the service was helpful and friendly.

This is a casual place that is warm and welcoming.  I will definately come back on another trip to San Francisco!  =o)
author: Heather K.

description:
This isn't quite East Coast Pizza but its OK.

I've had the lasagna and there were no complaints.  It's good if you don't want to go far from home, but if you are willing to make the journey to North Beach then that would be a better option for pizza and pasta.

Pizza Options
-Golden Boys
-Tomasso's

Pasta
-Tomasso's
author: Po L.

description:
I use to love ordering from Amici's, both for their pizza and their pasta.

I live just over a mile away in Dogpatch in a clean loft building and yet they just called me to refuse my online order because they've had three drivers robbed in our neighborhood.

While I feel for their drivers and share their concern about safety, I feel that this is part of the territory of that job.

I dislike Goat Hill, so what now, Domino's? Feh.
author: Alex R.

description:
Came here a few times to eat before we headed over to the Giants game.  Depending on what time you are out there, the wait time is different.  We've had pretty good service.  

Pizza was good and came out quick.  I was disappointed that they took out their tuna sandwich off their menu.  I use to get that all the time when I wasn't in the mood for pizza.  But I'm glad that they kept their garlic breadsticks.  Also one of my favorites.  

Will be back for more when we see the Giants again.
author: Shana W.

description:
This location and visit was better than when I tried the union street location a couple of years ago, but I wasn't overly impressed.  The salad was very good this time, but the pizza was bland other than the burnt crust.

I wondered why the waitress kept rushing us, even when there were many empty tables, but I soon found out when I inserted my validated parking ticket into the machine and found that Amici's only gives you 20 minutes to eat.  And that's not intended for takeout - the sign back at the payment machine said that is for dine in only!
author: Andrew N.

description:
Amici's has pretty good pizza but it's not the New York pizza that I've had in Brooklyn or Queens.  I've tried the Margherita, Amici's combo (pep, bacon, meatball, olives), pepperoni, and one with chicken (can't remember the name).  They're all good.  If you like garlic, you can add fresh garlic that gets sprinkled and roasted on your pizza at no extra charge.  My favorite part of Amici's is the pepperoni that they use.  They use miniature-sized pepperoni that curls up when cooked.  Yum!

Their meatball sandwich and eggplant parmagiana on penne are also very good if you're not in the mood for pizza.  Their sandwich bread is crusty but chewy at the same time.
author: Nina L.

description:
Ok here's the deal.

I LOVE pizza... i really do, but I LOVE money more... anyone disagree?

Amici's seems to do some bad things consistently... read all the reviews below and 70% talk about burning the bottom... and if that's how they do it in new york... that sucks for new york.  Also the pizza turns soggy. I have been here 3 times (being dragged by my ex) and everytime I was shocked at the repeats of these stupid things.

Also PRICE is everything when it comes to food. Why have a personal size pizza that is 10" for over $10??? At least CPK has over a footlong diameter and they are more "gormet" then Amicis... for less. It sucks to have a meal of 4 10" pizzas with friends and the whole meal be over $60 with tips... this isn't fine dining.

The whole place seems to rely on the fact that the ballpark is across the street and that people blindly spend money on days of the games. I just don't understand how I can walk across the street and get a good 2 slices of pizza from a bar, which would have more square footage than the 10" pizza, and it cost half the price and not be soggy and burnt.

I REALLY want to love this place cause I enjoy pizza places... but they seem to do everything wrong... except service is nice... so that's why they get two stars.
author: Preston B.

description:
Three and a half stars (extra half for good vegan mozzarella, see below). Good food and great service! I also like that they deliver (something I miss about NYC) and stay open until 10pm, which provides a casual dining venue that is open on the later side in this neighborhood. 

I started off with a bowl of minestrone soup - the bowl was enough to satisfy. My wife ordered a mini pollo pizza (chicken, spinach, slow-roasted garlic) with vegan mozzarella (which was tasty, to my wife's delight, and was much better than other vegan cheeses that I've had). Two thumbs up for the roasted garlic, too - delicious and just the right amount of garlic to provide a robust garlic taste without overpowering the other flavors. I ordered a small margherita pizza. The pizza was good in its own right, but was not the New York-style margherita pizza that I have been accustomed to. You will not find slices of Buffalo mozzarella on a bed of tomato sauce, but Amici's margherita is good. The crust on both pizzas, though not quite New York, is close and has a good balance of crispiness and chewiness. 

We rounded out the meal with side of chilled broccoli in olive oil and lemon juice; it served its purpose as our veggie for the night, but the edges were a bit brown. 

We'll certainly go back for more pizza (and vegan mozzarella cheese).
author: Chris T.

description: I ordered pizza from this restaurant because it was  3 minute walk from my apartment. I ordered a large pepperoni pizza for my boyfriend and I to split. Having lived in New York I know how expensive a slice can be and what it should taste like. I must say I was disappointed. The taste was mediocre at best and got worse as time went on. I give it three stars because it is close and convenient and I would try again.
author: Knickerbocker R.

description:
OMG!  This pizza seriously sucks east coast a_s!

Is this their not too subtle way of telling us west coasters that people in the east like their pizza burned to a carbon crisp?

My office orders from them every now and then and seriously every freakin' pizza is black on the bottom.  

If I could I wouldn't even give it a star.
author: Gemma V.

description:
im rating the pizza and the ceasar's salad.

when he has his craving, he has his craving. so when he was feening for the thin crust pizza, we got it from here, he wants me to try the caesar's salad, he knows i dont like greens that much and how i put hella dressing and cheese in every salad i ordered, he asked for some extra  ..now isnt that sweet.

my fave pizza is shakeys which they only have in LA, but i would go for new york style anytime.

we will definitely have this to-go again. ;-)
author: Malou C.

description: Visited Amici's last night before the Giants game, three hours before so it was not busy yet. We ordered one side salad, one dinner salad with dressing on the side, and one mini pizza. We received two side salads both with dressing on them, followed by a mini pizza with charred crust. Both of our side salads were on very small plates, which would have been fine except the lettuce leaves were around eight inches long and needed to be cut with a knife. This made the salad fall off the plate, along with the dressing. What a mess. We complained about the one salad being a side salad and they offered to replace it. We decided to see if it was enough, but we later opted for a second side salad to supplement the first. We brought up the fact that the salad dressing was not on the side, and asked if they could make sure it would be on the side this time. They said of course. The side salad was later delivered, smothered in dressing. The crust of the pizza as I had mentioned was charred, and the taste was fair at best. Sadly we will not be back. We will look elsewhere going forward.
author: Brent J.

description:
This place isn't cheap considering it's pizza, so minus one star for the price.  You can get the 3 medium pizzas special from Dominos for 1 large here.  I have no complaints about the food itself - which is the important part.  My favorite is the Amici's Combo.  Pepperoni, Meatball, Bacon, Sauted Mushrooms, and Black Olives.  

I don't like thick crusts, so the thin crust of these pizzas totally suits my fancy.  Start it off with the Caesar salad and you're good to go.

On game days (Go Giants), check outside for the pizza by the slice table.  No waiting and instant satisfaction.  Of course, they only have limited toppings like pepperoni or cheese.
author: Denise M.

description: I like Amici's near AT&T Park alot.  Often before or after a game, I eat here and park in the (Safeway) parking lot that the restaurant building is attached.  It makes it soooo convenient.  The spinach salad is very good and is a meal in itself.  The pizza is thin crust, always good, and comes out quick. The menu has a good variety of pizza's, salads and other items.  They have a full bar and a counter that you can sit at inside and an outdoor area in front along King St. that has patio heaters.  The biggest draw back about this Amici's is that if you sit inside, you will be sitting almost on top of the customers next to you because they have the tables so close together.  Fortunately, most of us who are in there on game days are SF fans!  Even on game days, when its packed, the service has been fast and the food good.   GO GIANTS!
author: Debra G.

description:
we had a great experience at Amici's last night before the game. it was super busy, but service was very pleasant.

we got half veggie and half greek isle with an artichoke salad, everything was fresh and very tasty. there crust squares in the salad in place of croutons and that was very yummy. the crust in the pizza was excellent! we got thin crust.

i will definitely be back and will try the Mountain View location as well.
author: Tracy C.

description:
I haven't been much of a pizza gal since moving to California-especially SF..why would I? There are hundreds of other fantastic options to eat, but I like this place. Not as good as Gino's East or Connie's Pizza from Chicago but good enough!

Try the Spicy Chicken Pizza-really anything with cilantro gets me good everytime!
author: Amruta G.

description: Delicious and right around the corner from my work. It will be hard to resist now that I've discovered how close it is. We started with the caesar salad and it was really good. I loved how the dressing was super cheesy and garlicky. We also shared a small NY cheese pizza w/ fresh garlic and sprinkled parsley. It was so so so good, even though I'll be radiating garlic for the next week. Especially good with a side of ranch, but I mean when is pizza not good with ranch?? Everything came out quickly, and we were back to our offices in under an hour. Perfect.
author: Sonya D.

description:
We came here right before the Giant's game on a Friday evening, so it was jam packed. All of the tables inside and outside were filled so we had a short wait. Luckily, we were sat inside because it was freezing cold that night. The restaurant decor is similar to a California Pizza Kitchen - it's pretty much standard. I wasn't sure what to expect since I don't eat pizza or any of the likes often, but I sure was craving it. 

The menu is expansive with items ranging from pizzas to pastas and soups/salads. The pizza sizes range from a Mini to a Large, so from ~$10 to ~$25. We ended up ordering a medium sized Siciliano pizza (~$21) with a large Sierra Nevada (~$5)  for Joe and a water for me. The pizza came without tomato sauce, but instead was very cheesy. There was mozarella and provolone cheese, lots of garlic, broccoli, Italian sausage, and pepper flakes all on top of a thin crust that came out piping hot and flaky. I really don't like eating thick or regular crusts, so I was happily relieved to see that the pizzas are all thin crusted. I really enjoyed the taste, especially with the garlic and the bit of spice coming from the pepper flakes. The sausage had a smokey flavor to it which made it taste even better and complimented the flavors of the pizza. The pizza size was great, we ended up having 3 pieces leftover! 

Our server was kind of attentive but we hardly saw her throughout the meal, which was fine because we understood she had about 8 other tables to attend to since it was right before a game. They also charge a Health Insurance tax for their employees... I've never seen that before so that was interesting... Hm.
author: Kristina K.

description:
We ordered three varieties: combo, veggie, some philly thing.. opened em up and they all looked exactly the same--burnt and shriveled. Seriously, their pies look like they've gone through a couple cycles of radiation and a dip in surface finish. The taste? Whatever. If it was a 3 for $10 pack at Safeway, I could pass up the quality for the value. But that certainly wasn't the case.

A couple minutes into our slices, someone asked, "Ever have a slice at Costco?" to which everyone mmm'd and aahhh'd, wishing it was that instead. Shoot, I'd even settle for a rice cake.
author: Michael A.

description:
Had it delivered twice, and both times the crust was burnt.

Is it really this difficult to find good pizza in San Francisco?!
author: Eric G.

description:
I ordered a pizza from Amici's on the way home from work and was told it would take ten minutes.  I was suprised it would only take ten minutes, since it was a game day.  I showed up in ten minutes and picked up my pizza.  Three minutes later I was at home ready to enjoy a slice and a beer after a long day at work.  Opened up the box, and looked at a pizza that was probably cooked forty five minutes ago, and spent way too much time in the oven.  The bottom of the pizza was a consitent black crust.  This was not an oven blister, but a constant burn.  

I call up Amici's and was immediately asked, "have you ever had our pizza before?"

No, but this pizza is burnt.  They told me they would give me a credit, or I could come back. 

Have you changed the pizza game?  New groundbreaking pizza methods?

On the way back to the restaurant, I looked at pizzas on the outside table.  They were all normal looking pizzas, not burnt.  

When I went in I showed them the pizza, and they said this was normal.  I've been in the restaurant business for over 15 years, so I was a little unnerved at the response from someone in the service industry.  No apology, just an excuse!  You should order your pizza under cooked?  Next time I will go to a real pizzeria.  

if you mistake, admit your mistake, and rectify the situation.  Do not lie to a customer.  Also, if you are going to charge twenty+ for a pizza, do not precook the pizza, even if it is a game day!
author: Tom F.

description: My BF and I live in the neighborhood and there are very few pizza delivery options, we gave Amici's a try and were sorely let down.  We both felt a frozen pizza from the grocery store would have been better (not to mention cheaper).  No problem with the delivery, just sub par pizza.
author: Maia H.

description:
Perfect location almost right across from AT&T Park, Amichi's does a nice job getting you pumped up for the Giants game, but can be inconsistent with the food. While the meat pizza was quite good, the veggie pizza was almost tasteless, and while the waitress said that we would be only half-charged for added toppings on half a pizza, we were charged full price anyway. The salads were fine, and the service was properly attentive. 
Later, I had one delivered to my hotel room after a game and the meat pizza was terrible.  For the price, I was expecting some better care and quality, but too up and down for me to return.
author: Jeff B.

description: I love this pizza.  I don't care if it's twice as expensive, I like it three times as much, so really I'm getting a deal.  The Trentino pizza and the Manhattan Red Clam pizza are both all time faves; but honestly it's all good stuff.  They even have lactose free cheese, but I didn't like that so much the one time I tried it.  Also, free delivery within the neighborhood!  Woohoo!
author: Tasha D.

description: I thought this place had really excellent pizza.  My roommate and I got delivery (even though it's like two blocks from our apartment) and it came within the time frame they advertised.  They will also supply utensils, etc. if you ask.  One tiny problem with my order (I asked for no onions and they took off the red onions but not the green) but otherwise everything was delicious.  I'd definitely order from here again or maybe stop in for dinner some time.
author: KT R.

description: I came here late Weds night with a group of friends.  We got a large pizza (1/2 veggie, 1/2 margherita).  The pizza was great - very thin, crispy crust with just enough cheese & sauce.  I highly recommend the margherita pizza - it's very tasty, and really hits the spot during a night out.
author: Bee M.

description: I have been coming to Amicis for years, and until last night, they get my first poo-poo. The food is super, the waitress are hella fine. Last night however, I was upset. Thats why they get 4/5 stars. I went alone for a late dinner, they sat me in the very corner, which is fine, i was alone. But where they lost me, is when they lost me. It took the guy, not even lying, about 20 minutes even acknowledge me. Then he took me order, blah blah blah. Aside from last night, I have never had a bad experience here.
author: Jorge P. G.

description:
I got a New York Pizza with Daiya, caramelized onions, roasted green peppers, and sauteed mushrooms. The pizza was very good! They used fresh mushrooms (a lot of places used canned which are disgusting) and the onions were actually caramelized. 

The crust is thin (as a New York pizza should be) and they cook them in a brick oven so the crust is nice and crunchy. Delicious!
author: Carly W.

description: Very good 'za. Reasonably priced pints.  Great place to meet before a Giants game.
author: Ted R.

description:
The pizza at this place is pretty good if you're willing to take out a second mortgage.  The last time I ordered here it came out to roughly $40 for the two of us for pizza and a salad.  Seriously!  This is just pizza.  Another time I was there for lunch with some guys at we all left hungry because we didn't want to spend more than $20 each for a pizza lunch.  

The problem is that out of the half a dozen places we've ordered from Amici's has the best pizza.  They also have a nice interior to the restaurant so it is a good place to go out for lunch or dinner.  I'll probably knock them down to three stars once I find a place with equally good pizza for less.
author: Garrett D.

description:
I picked up my pal and asked if we could eat something light cuz I was having tummy problems all day long. (you know, the kind of problems you have after a long night of drinking alcoholic bevs).

We headed to Amici's since it was close to his job... oh man! I didn't expect much and maybe that's why it was so good?!? We ordered a small Margherita Pizza... Mozzarella, Tomatoes, Fresh Basil, Olive Oil. Oh YUM! Thin crust, not doughey, good flavors, and light. 

Good... but not amazing. But most importantly, I was happy-full :)  I would definitely go there again.
author: Hana N.

description:
My feelings towards this place are lukewarm.
Yes, the pizza is good but sadly, it's not really a good value for your money.  The option of the mini size CAN be a blessing in disguise if you're into portion controlled food.

I've tried both the red clam pizza along with the eggplant parmigiana sandwich on different occasions.  The pizza was tasty but tiny.  While the sandwich was good, the baguette was pretty burnt, and I wasn't in the mood for Cajun food.  Served alongside the tiniest pickle I've ever set my eyes on--they really shouldn't be so generous.   One of my co-workers was really disappointed with her tuna sandwich.

The pizza was clearly  the winner here.  I would suggest staying away from the sandwiches.
author: Manny P.

description:
When I think of Amici's, I think of colon cancer pizza. Why?  The crust bottom is always charred black. Have they never heard of golden, brown delicious? Is that how it's done on the east coast? I'll take thin crust California pansy pizza any day.

Crust aside, it's good pizza, especially if it's free and the boss is payin.
author: Pea H.

description:
To put it simply, I like this place because:
1) the location is close enough to home such that I can pick it up and take it home pretty easily
2) they have soy cheese
3) their pizza is light, and doesn't weigh me down (thin crust)
4) their antipasto salad is good (and HUGE--the half order is enough for 2-3 people)
5) carmelized onions!
6) the veg pizza isn't all watery, like some places can be.

Tip: if you like it saucy, order it with extra sauce.  They tend to skimp a bit.
author: Sarah R.

description:
The only positive things I can say about this place are that it's close to my house and your order is usually ready pretty quickly. 
The pizza is flaccid and flavorless. It needs some serious doctoring with the chile flakes, oregano, and parmesan to have any flavor whatsoever.  No thanks.
author: Michelle A.

description: Much cozier spot than the one on Union. Same great taste.
author: Miriam W.

description: Everyone has their favorite styles of pizza; Amici's is not my favorite.  Roasted veggi topping was too oily & the crust was not so good.  I've tried their non-pizza items also, but they were o.k., but nothing special.  I would rather go to Pazzia on 3rd for their thin crust pizza.
author: トモ T.

description: Generally good pizza for San Francisco.  Meat toppings tend to be salty and greasy.  Veggie and plain versions are a better bet.  The margherita is good, and perhaps the biggest surprise is a really lovely New Haven White clam pizza.
author: Peter L.

description:
this is definitely an incomplete review... because ive only had pasta! i had a craving for pasta, and it seems that many of the soma italian places have closed over time.

anyway- ordered fettuccine with meat sauce and added meatballs. the meat sauce is delicious - a little spicy. the meatballs (4 of them for $3.50) are larger... not quite as tasty, but still good. fettuccine is always wonderful.

prices are a tad steep (came to $14 for just pasta) but can't complain. nothing spectacular... but i'll try to the pizza next time!

oh- and a note. i ordered it through the website (waiter.com) and it was ready when they said it was ready! that is... a huge... deal. =D
author: Bethany K.

description: Drooooooolllll! Vegan pizza is the best! The vegan cheese they use is almost the best I have had, ever! I thought that there were too many veggies in every single bite though, it was kind of overwhelming. The price was right and they were nice enough to give my daughter a kid sized portion of penne with meat sauce from the adult menu. She like it alot btw and said it was "perfectly meaty". Staff was helpful. Their bathroom soap smelled good? LOL
author: Momo C.

description: Wow, one of the best ways to finish off a Giants game to have a COLD beer and delicious pizza at Amici's.  When I first tasted it, I commented to my buddy that is was not that "great". My expectations were too high? BUt, as I continued to eat, it got better, and better, and now.... I CAN'T WAIT TO GET SOME MORE!
author: Dan V.

description: not sure what the love is with Amici's unless you like pizza with lots of grease.  It is good but not great.  certainly not like John's in NYC or the Jersey Shore boardwalk.
author: Tim F.

description:
I know there's a raging debate on whether this is really east coast style and if this place sucks or not. I like it a lot. I gew up in the east coast. Draw your own conclusions.

I really like the thin crust, the fold the pizza, the spicy chicken topping. I don't like the minimum order for delivery (you're a pizza place, right? and an expensive one. Geesh!). And for a while we boycotted them because they had a no dogs sign on their seats outside on a PUBLIC sidewalk.
But they took the sign down. They'll deliver to us if we're eating enough. And their meatballs are good (yeah, of course, I get everything w/ a side of meatballs. Including my pizza).
author: Margie L.

description:
This is one of my favorite New York-style pizza places in the Bay Area. Although their pizza is pretty damn expensive (for what you get), there are two things that will always keep me coming back:

1. The pesto pizza (but not with tomato sauce included) - This is one of the best pesto pizzas I've ever had!
2. Their chilled broccoli with olive oil and lemon - Great way to start out your meal.

My last two visits to Amici's were to the King Street location, and they were before the baseball season started. I can only imagine how crazy it must be before and after a game, but I think that's part of the allure of this location. I'll definitely grab a pie here before a game at Pac Bell/SBC/AT & T/Whatever the hell they'll name it next Park!
author: Art D.

description:
I had one negative experience recently with Sy K. at this place.  Did we have a large group?  Yes.  Was it reasonable to make us wait 45 minutes with a table available?  No!!!!  I was man hungry at the time too.  Granted, the big table that was available was dirty, but come on!  Grrrrr.  

That said, its still a decent neighborhood spot to grab a nice slice of thin crust pizza or a decent pasta.  During the summer, its nice to sit outside and enjoy the sun while reading a magazine that you, uhh, borrowed from Borders.
author: Jason S.

description:
Amici's pizza is pretty good.  However, do not be fooled by KNBR's Ralph Barbieri's shameless promotions of Amici's.  It's not the best place on earth, and it's not the only real East Coast pizza on the West Coast.

Amici's, however, offers an excellent pre-game meal for hungry Giants fans.  I come here about twice a month during baseball season.  Get here early, or risk not getting a table or being late for the first pitch.  On warmer days, you can try sitting outside if you don't mind the sounds of The Embarcadero traffic and the screams of overzealous scalpers.

Amici's features thin crust pizza, which is surprisingly non-greasy.  They have about 15 or so 'signature pizzas,'  or you can ask them to create your own with your favorite ingredients.  

If you order an Extra Large pizza, perfect for 2 hungry adult males, you can ask them to make it a half-and-half for $2 more.  We usually get 1/2 Amici's combo (Pepperoni, Meatballs, Bacon, Mushrooms and Black Olives) and 1/2 Calabria (Mozzarella, Provolone, Pancetta and Green Olives).  We also get a salad, but it's pretty boring.

The waitstaff is polite, experienced and prompt.  They're trying to serve you as quickly as possible, since an hour before the game, the line is usually out the door.  For a change, your needs and the needs of a restaurant are perfectly aligned.

If I had to find some downside, I'd say that pizza is really expensive here and there are no TVs.  However, if they did put TVs in the dining room and lowered their prices, you'd probably have to make reservations months in advance.
author: Yan G.

description:
I don't usually think that highly of chain restaurants, and my experience at Amici's solidified my disdain for mass-produced "food". Not only was my meal gross, it was horrifically expensive, and the portion was tiny.

If I had a soul establishments like this would hurt it.
author: Ricky J.

description:
Too tired from our flight to go out and wanting something to deliver to our hotel past 9 PM we ended up coming up with this place. They had a $25 minimum for delivery (is it just me or is that crazy high?), so we got a large pepperoni pizza.. which came out to $25 (again crazy expensive).

The pizza was just OK..nothing special and I definitely wouldn't order it again. The pepperonis were small and weird.. I haven't had another pepperoni like that in my life. I'm rounding up from 2.5 stars since delivery was quick and they delivered pseudo-late (9:30 PM)
author: Blair B.

description: These guys just pissed me off big time. I live FIVE HOUSES from 24th Street, the southern border of their delivery area, and they just told me ADAMANTLY that they won't deliver to my area IN BROAD DAYLIGHT. I tell them their delivery map says they deliver to me but they say they won't deliver. What gives? They have delivered to me several times before. I like their pizza. I'll never buy it again. Amici's, you just lost one good customer and gained a really pissed off detractor. Oh yeah, and I'm posting it on Facebook, too.
author: J.J. P.

description: Definitely have had better pizza, and for MUCH cheaper. The crust was burned, veggie toppings were overcooked and not that great... the whole thing was just really disappointing, especially for the price. You can find excellent pizza for half the price in North Beach. Won't be back here.
author: Jen N.

description: I'm very happy that my office orders us food all the time, but I'm saddened that it's from this place. The food is completely mediocre bordering on bad. Visually it's not appealing, and the flavor is lackluster, dull and makes me a little ill. I've tried their pizza and their pasta. Both were pretty bland and uninspiring. The pizza looks like it's been sitting out for several days, and it's this horrible pinkish-orange color as if somehow the cheese and the (very little) sauce has merged. It appears vomitlike. Steer clear of this place, there are plenty of superb pizzerias in this city, no need to waste your time here.
author: David Z.

description:
Good Pizza but East Coast implies NYC style, nope this is more like South Jersey style.
Nice staff though and decent overall.
author: Sean S.

description:
This place is alright.  I mean, surprisingly good (for some reason, I wasn't expecting much), but I still love other pizza places more than this (see: Pizza Orgasmica and Golden Boy Pizza).

But, they probably are one of my favourite thin crust pizza places.  It's just unfortunate that this place is NOWHERE near me and there is no way in hell they'll deliver to my bf and I out in Parkside.  Le sigh.
author: Dianne d.

description:
Good pizza, but it could have used more cheese.  Also, I'm glad we ordered it with the light crust as I'm not particularly fond of black spots on my crust.

It was also a tad expensive and they so need to get over themselves with the delivery thing.  They won't deliver to my street after dark and there was a $30 minimum.  Fortunately, we were able to meet that with a large pizza and and a small salad.  Too pricey.

Fine, they don't want to deliver to me, I won't order from them.  It wasn't good enough for all the trouble.

We just had New York Pizza Kitchen down the street.  Better sauce, more cheese and a large pizza was $16 - and they give you awesome coupons.

Amici's, thanks but no thanks.
author: Suze C.

description:
Definitely above average pizza.  But by the way the "Razor" on KNBR talks about it, it is the best pizza in the whole wide world.  Of course, everyone has their personal favorites but this just happens to not be mine.  

It's aight though, so I'll be back.  Until then.....
I'll just have to keep listening to the Razor put them on a throne....
author: Mark W.

description:
My favorite burnt brick oven thin crust pizza. 

Not a good spot for broke college students, it is expensive compared to heart clogging major franchise spots around the city.
author: Robin L.

description:
Sucks.

I mean, alright. Lemme try to be fair. I'm a stark, raving conservative about on thing in this world and that's pizza. But c'mon! Don't call yourself "East Coast Pizza" and then deliver this disappointment on a tin dish. If anyone reading this is even vaguely familiar with New York style pizza then it's your duty to avoid this place and call out all places like this for what they are: marketing money machines. 

Sauce: Well it's red. It's also weak. The sauce makes the pizza, folks. If you believe a pizza sauce doesn't need flavor because your idea of good pizza = as many toppings as you can fit on it? Well, you're silly but you can also enjoy this better than I.
Cheese: hot and greasy (which is good) but far too much Parmesan.
Crust: burned, brittle, no flavor.
Worst of all, the large pizza I ordered was about 15" (where's the 16th inch? Did you eat it? *cries*) and costs more than an 18" in most other pizzaria places that serve the crap which many people in San Francisco call good.

If you want pizza that is worth the calories and fat intake? Grab one from Villa Romana on Irving street. But if you want to brag to your friends that you ate at an overpriced marketing ploy where the best thing you can say is it burned the roof of your mouth? Well, you're Amici's exists for such fools.
author: Ben S.

description:
Isn't one of the points of ordering delivery on a rainy night so you won't get wet? I always tip twice as much on these days cause I know the driver doesn't want to be out there either. 

Ok so the delivery guy couldn't understand "go thru the gate, pass the mailboxes and make your first left  - I'll meet you there" or "left, left - I'm at the door". He never even passed the mailboxes. UGH!!!

2 soggy pizzas later and I'm drenched like a soaked poodle. I open the boxes and half the ingredients were left off and they're cold and burnt. Double UGH!!! 

They got a couple stars for giving me credit towards a future order, but I won't be back. The pizza is ok at best even when you dine in and delivery quality is not worth the price. Delivery = $25 min order
author: T G.

description:
Amici is a nice spot to kind of chill before going to a Giants game or just a lazy afternoon and you don't feel like cooking or going far away from home. You a spot to go just to get out the house. 

The staff is pretty cool I've taken the time to get to know a few of them. The pizza is ok and of course some are better than others but nothing to write home to mom about.  

My favorite pizza is the Spicy Pepper Chicken on the thin crust. Its not very spicy but they over did the cilantro. 

So yeah check it out it worthy of 3 stars and its the one bright spot in the whole Mission Bay area.
author: Karim R.

description: Rubbery & cold, with burnt edges. Only a tiny bit of sauce in the first bite towards the middle. Very skimpy with their poor quality dime-sized pepperoni.
author: Pam S.

description: Not impressed by their pizza at all. Maybe they're trying to serve East Coast style pizza with the thin crusts and I'm more of a thick crust fan, but even so, not delicious at all. I had the mini vegetarian pizza and it was very plain. I've had better pizza coming from the frozen aisle at the supermarket. I didn't try their pasta, so I can't say how good that is, but judging from their pizza I won't be going back to even try it.
author: Robin I.

description: Ok I don't get it, why do people love this place? My old job used to order from here all the time for special events and the pizza was always really greasy! I've only had it delivered so maybe it gets soggy and greasy only when delivered? I really don't know. The travel to our work was not that far since Amicis is in SOMA and we are at SOMA also. Meh! no like! I always asked them to change it up and order from Escape from NY instead.
author: Karen T.

description: We made it to Amaici's 3 hours before the Giants game & it was excellent. The service was great & quick. I ordered the Spinach Salad & Lasagna with meat sauce. The Spinach salad was amazing.
author: Juan D.

description:
Amicis has excellent thin crust pizza with unique toppings.  I also adore the eggplant pasta dish and the spinach salad.  They also deliver in record times.

Why only three stars?  Two reasons:  the prices are steep and $25 minimum for delivery is annoying.
author: Lynn F.

description:
Greasy + overpriced + burnt crust (made our hands black) = not worth it.

After hearing all of the hype about this place, I was looking forward to trying their pizzas out, but I was really disappointed with the pies that we ordered. I think I'd rather have a $1 Tostinos pizza. At least I'd be getting what I paid for.

+1 extra star for their selection of toppings...
author: Victoria D.

description:
Amici's is both the first pizza I ever had in the bay area (San Mateo, July of 2000) and the pizza closest now to where I live (a block from my house). My husband and I order from them when we don't feel like waiting 45 minutes to an hour for Extreme Pizza. 

That is not to say that Amici's has bad pizza--it is great pizza! It just, for whatever reason, does not inspire us nearly as much as Extreme, and I know that for me that is partially due to the nature of the crust. Sometimes the crust does not reheat well or last into the next day, and can be rough on my jaw, which already has problems.

That said, and before everyone thinks I am a hypochondriac or whatever else you might be thinking, their pesto pizza is FANTASTIC, I love their raw garlic, and it is much cheaper than going to Extreme.
author: Amber G.

description:
Decent selection of topping choices for pizza.

Pollo Pizza/Veggie pizza..yumm

Selection of pasta/salads and sandwicheson the menu,but who would want a sandwich?

Decent place near the ballpark to try out.
author: Dani D.

description:
Guilt-free, delicious pizza! I'm a health nut and thought my days of enjoying a couple slices were over. Not until I moved up the street from Amici's. You can order any pizza with the reduced crb, extra thin crust. Some pizza places don't cook the crust all the way. So if you move the toppings you see gooey dough- yuck. The thin crust is so good, not crispy thin, just perfect!

I love the pollo pizza with fresh garlic. I also love the spinach salad with bacon, pine nuts, feta and roasted red peppers. This place has the BEST ranch dressing, too. I know, not really diet food. 

I'm not sayin' this is "diet" food, but I enjoy it now about once a week. I don't feel stuffed or bloated. Headsup, you have to order marinara sauce on the side bc a lot of the pies don't have any on them. It's not cheap, but what is these days?

Thanks for making a pizza I can enjoy without feeling like there's lead in my gut the next morning!
author: cali c.

description:
so the 3 stars is an average (a high average, if you're into math and accuracy) based on the following two aspects of amici's:

5 stars for the vegan cheese daiya pizza amazingness, 1 star for the icky experiences I've had eating here, specifically with gross yuppie SOMA parents who bring their babies/toddlers and use their iPhone or portable DVD player (at top volume, of course) as a tableside babysitter. Each time I've come to this Amici's to ravage a delicious vegan pizza I've had funky interactions with rude fellow patrons who make me happy to not live in SOMA. Eating at this Amici's is fun if you sit at the counter and watch the pizzas being made, or if your party is maybe loud enough to drown out the sounds of whatever baby einstein crap the people at the table next to you are playing for their zombie kid while they talk about shopping for their pomeranian or whatever. I've had good experiences with the servers here but my pizzas are gonna have to be take-out from now on.
author: M M.

description: was not happy about having to microwave an overpriced pizza right after it was delivered
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Some of us ate here after work today and I noticed on their menu that slimy little line item that's cropping up more often:  On top of our published prices, we will add $somePercentage to your check because we're butthurt about the Healthy San Francisco program.

Enough!  From now on, these unconscionable outfits get a onestar, regardless of any other consideration!

1)  Food and drink are so profitable it's almost ridiculous.  When I worked part-time (20hrs / week or more) for a coffee shop a while back, I had full benefits... medical, dental, 401k, stock, everything... with no inducement necessary from any government to treat us humanely.  And our fairly small store made the company $750K a year (that's net... not gross), on an average check of just $3.75!  The only reason Healthy San Francisco was necessary in the first place was pure and completely unmitigated greed.

2)  You really, Really, REALLY want to maintain your insanely high margin?  Fine.  Be open and honest about it and raise your actual posted prices!  Don't sneak in a "surcharge" in small print with a snarky one-liner that's a transparent attempt to turn me against my fellow man.

Bottom line:  I know what the margins are like.  If you're so grossly incompetent that you can't make a good profit and still treat your employees like actual human beings, then you don't deserve to be in business.  And you won't be getting my business!
author: John B.

description:
Meh.  Average pizza, very greasy, kind of coldish.  

I remember this chain from my startup days in the mid-Peninsula.  They're worth three stars.  No more.  No less.
author: Apollo L.

description:
Amici's is great for a completely casual dining experience.  If you're not expecting too much out of your pizza, or your company, then this is the place to go.

The pizza is thin crust and tends to be slightly dry.  The menu options look promising, but a large number of them end up being a little bland.  The spicy pepper chicken stands out as a great pizza and probably the best of the lot.

The non-pizza fare is decent.  I've had the four cheese lasagna, which was somewhat reminiscent of elementary school cafeteria food.  It was entirely serviceable and probably supplied the requisite essential nutrients to my body.  That's all I'm asking for at this point.

Finally, I think the prices are quite high in comparison to the type of restaurant Amici's competes with.  Expect to see similar prices in more upscale places.

Despite everything I've said, it's not terrible food and I'll be back at some point.
author: Rajiv B.

description:
I've eaten Amici's pizza a hundred times, but only once in their actual restaurant! My BF and I order delivery from Amici's at least a couple of times a month, and we're never dissatisfied. Their thin crusts are super yummy, and I love love love their Polla Pizza! They're relatively expensive for a pizzeria, but how many delivery options are there in SF? Not many...

Their pasta dishes are solid, as well -- lasagna, spaghetti...everything's yummy.
author: Joyce S.

description:
Pizza has always been good when I've been there, seems lil pricey, but not by much... specially for the area. 

Salads aren't the best. 

Haven't tried any pasta dishes yet.

Service needs work. Most of the waitresses I've come across when I've visited seem like they'd rather be anywhere else but there.
author: Kimberly P.

description:
If you are not afraid of strong and bold flavors, and have that palate to take it, go to Amici's for their caesar dressing.  I ain't kidding.  This review is not about their pizza.  It is only for my one and only caesar.  Mi me gusta, no! Me amo caesar.  I love their caesar dressing over their garden salad.  It is, hands down, the BEST caesar dressing.  For all of it's anchoviness, tartness, garlic-iness, parmesan-iness and bold bold flavor goodness.  The way it is just not afraid to be so anchovy-ish, makes my mouth water just thinking about it.

Second best is my husband's home made caesar dressing which took us quite a few days to perfect.  What did we learn kids?  Hmm?  The secret is to not be afraid.  Just go for the anchovy, just go for it.  Be kind on the garlic and the lemon, as well as the salt, which should only accent and bring out the anchovy, but the true star, by far, is the anchovy.  That is why the caesar dressing at Amici's is my favorite.  They knew to go insane on the anchovy.  Somehow they just knew.
author: Mary Ann K.

description:
Went for a beer with a few friends the other day before the baseball game.  Ordered a couple of pitchers and discovered the pitchers spill all over the place when you pour the first beer. Our waiter was good enough to give us an extra beer for our troubles.  However, I was surprised after I left that our waiter charged us TWICE for our beer.  While I was in the restroom, the other couple I was with paid for their pitcher.  When I came out, I went to the cash to pay as we needed to head out quickly.  The waiter gave me a bill for 2 pitchers, which I paid (and tipped nicely as he had given us an extra beer!).  I was surprised later when I found out that we had paid TWICE for one pitcher of beer and he never said anything to us.  He intentionally gave me a bill for 2 pitchers after one of them had already been paid for!

I worked in the service industry for 6 years and I would never have done this.  Watch out for server 66Thomas... he rips people off!
