author: Jess H.

description: I had never eat-ten here before and i must say I'm more then impressed. I when with my husband after a Giants game and was suprised cause we where seated immediately. We both order separate mini pizzas mine with extra thin crust cause i try to reduce carbs where i can. It was hot when it got to us and there was not a huge soggy mess on the crust it was all proportioned great and i will defiantly come back. Between the food and the great services it cant be beat.
author: Amber H.

description: My family and I were driving past Amici's and decided to try it out. We ordered a large margarita pizza for 4 people. The slices were pretty big and filling since there was a good amount of cheese on it. I would say the pizza was good but nothing about it was extraordinary, especially for the amount they charge. The service was friendly but a bit pushy. The manager kept pushing us to get more food or asking if the pizza would be enough for four people (which it was). Overall, it was decent. I'm sure there are better pizza joints in San Francisco but if you're in the area and craving pizza, this would be a place to check out.
author: Krishna S.

description: I'm not the biggest pizza fan, but it's easy. Came here after fan fest at AT&T Park. Ordered the "philly" pizza. Damn good! Everything about it was good. Service was excellent.
author: Mike N.

description: I guess some people love it, some hate it. I personally love it. Much better than that greasy stuff you find at fast food pizza places.
author: Mike R.

description:
The personnel at the King Street location are always so .... Nice! While the pizza here is excellent, I've taken to ordering the Artichoke Panzanella Salad, a classic Tuscan bread salad with hearts, cukes, small tomatoes, red onion, romaine, generous basil strips, capers, but with the Caesar dressing on the side as I find Amici's red-wine vinegar dressing too vinegar-y. The small version of this salad is only $8.50, generous enough for an entire meal. The larger version ($14.75) is said to serve as many as 4, but I think it would be a good dinner size for 2. 

I think Amici's prices are high, but again you do have a dining-room experience (with the pleasure of the variety of King Street walking by). This is quieter than most pizzeries (except on game days). We had a party of 6 on a Monday night and were able to conduct a normal conversation with no interference. 

In the summer, it's fun to sit at one of the small tables on the sidewalk.
author: joyce h.

description:
One thing I do not understand is why pizza is so expensive in SF!  It is barely half as good as it is NY and and more than twice the price.

On a recent visit here, I had a chicken Caesar salad.  It was what you might expect to get at an airport as you rush to your meal-less flight.  The chicken was cold and slimy just like at the airport.  It did not taste like it had been prepared fresh for the salad.

Next, we had a $25 pizza!  I'm sorry but a medium pizza with three sparse toppings should cost no more than $15 as it basically about 3 slices of NY pizza.  Why is pizza making so hard west of the Hudson?
author: Jeff P.

description:
I did not have high expectations when I ordered from Amici's and I was still disappointed. gggrrrrr....

Pizza arrived on time which was good.  But it was cold already- not even warm like it's been made an hour ago.

The toppings were skimpy, the crust was hard and brunt.

Will never order from this place again.
author: J S.

description:
Amici's is overpriced for the quality of food.  Pesto is oily, chicken is very dry, house salad is basically two pieces of lettuce and a quarter tomato (not chopped ... just given to you in a big chunk).

If you were to be forced to eat here, there are only two things I recommend (well, maybe three - if you include the meatball sandwich ... but I'm not a meatball sandwich connoisseur, so I'll only say that I personally thought it was decent): (1) margherita pizza w/ artichoke hearts added, and (2) lasagna.

Oh, and if your waiter/waitress disappears for 35 minutes, apparently that's 'normal' ... luckily, whenever we've had bad service, boy has been wearing his red sox hat and another server has happened to be a fan, so they've helped us out.  Otherwise, I probably wouldn't have had a chance to try any of the food we ordered because it never would have come.

INSTEAD OF AMICI'S ... get some real thin crust pizza that's delish and fresh at South Beach Cafe (4 minute walk down King/Embarcadero - 6 minute walk max), or order delivery pizza from Goat Hill.
author: Kristen H.

description:
Love this place.  They found my apartment, which is NOT easy, because you would be surprised HOW MANY  PIZZA places do not understand HOW TO LOOK UP a last name and hit CALL to ring our apartment !! UGGGG !  

Also the delivery driver dude communicated with me, which hardly ever happens either.  

I mean come on.  How hard is it to take my credit card number over the phone, find out where I live, and bring me a pizza.  For the LOVE OF GOD.

IT is so frustrating to communicate with half of the pizza places in this town.

Amici's delivery was so fast ! Way Faster than Mr. Pizza Man, Extreme Pizza.   Which i have problems with delivery with these jack *sses EVERY time i order from them.

My one bitching point about them is they are really overpriced for the quality of the pizza we got, our pizza was cold when we go it, but the flavor is Very good.     I will overlook that because of how easy they were to order from and how fast they got to our apartment. 

But i will definatly order from them again because the ingredients were fresh, the delivery time was great, and they were friendly and had good communication skills.
author: Rachel G.

description:
If you go to the Amici's website you'll see this slogan: "Enjoy a Taste of New York Right Here in California." I'm going to suggest that you beware this slogan, nay that you fear it like you fear being alone every Saturday night with your 50 cats and misplaced cups of lukewarm chamomile tea.

I break this down to one real issue, the bottoms of the pizza are always burned. If that's New York style, you can keep it Big Apple. The number of bottom burns I've eaten at Amici's makes me wonder if when the distribution tractor trailer pulls up in the back alley, you wouldn't perhaps see boxes of "Acme New York Homeless Dude Fire Pit Ashes" being off-loaded by the dolly full. This is a real bummer actually, because without the burns the crusts threaten to taste pretty good and are appropriately thin and crispy, if that's your thing.

It's also pricey for what you get, and there are cheaper, better meals to be had in the area. If you like it burned I won't judge you, and you should give Amici's a try if that's the case. Me personally, if it's nice out I would prefer the pizzas at South Beach Cafe which is just a stroll down the Embarcadero. It's important to note that I haven't tried any of their other entrees, so they might be the cat's pajamas at non-pizza dishes.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Apparently, Amici's touts it pizza as "East Coast style." Apparently, this is offensive to some people.

Well, I didn't even notice. I was focused on the fucking awesome pizza.

Normally I am not a fan of any chain restaurant, local or otherwise, yet Amici's is exceptional. I am a simple man when it comes to pizza; pepperoni is the right choice just about every time. And yes, Amici's makes a fine pie. They've used their chain money advantageously and purchased a fleet of extremely high powered ovens which they use to blacken their thin crust pizzas. This does not count as burnt! Let me assure you that they do it on purpose and that it tastes delicious. 

Amici's is excellent pizza in a restaurant setting. The salads and pasta are fine if you're there with some... one... who doesn't like pizza. Service and atmosphere are good, nothing to notice or care about.

It's a little unfortunate that some of the best pizza in San Francisco comes from a chain. Part of me wishes there was a little side street joint with incredible, cheap pizza served on flimsy paper plates that I could go to a few times a week. Part of me wants to go back to Amicis.
author: Jackson G.

description:
I have very mixed feelings about Amici's.
pluses: addictively good caesar dressing; yummy garlic breadsticks with fresh basil; tasty baked penne w/ breaded eggplant in it; nice array of more unusual pizza toppings (and I really appreciate that it's free to add fresh garlic!)
minuses: generally too expensive for what you get; pizza dough is odd--thin and slightly blackened yet not crispy, and is instead a bit rubbery; restaurant itself has zero ambiance and spotty service in my experience.

Enough goodness to keep me coming back (or at least ordering delivery), but not enough to make me crave Amici's when I'm in the mood for pizza.
author: Marissa R.

description: I am a PIZZA LOVER. But Amicis is nothing more than OK. When you live in the second biggest food capital in America, and you have amazing joints like Golden Boy, Little Star, Pizzetta 211 and Za, why would you ever go to this corporate, money grubbing, half decent tasting pizzeria?? Even corporate chains like Escape from New York, Blondies or Paxtis are better that Amicis. And for how it tastes, it's way overpriced. I even live on top of an Amicis and i don't even eat there. I'd rather drive across the city to Pizza Orgasmica or Nizarios or Seniores  in Parkside than eat at Amicis. Or eat a Safeway Select pizza or a slice from Costco. Not sure what the big fuss is with the 4 to 5 stars, but if you haven't been to any of the places i mentioned above and still love Amicis, I'm at a loss for words.
author: Alex H.

description: I'm frm the east coast, and they do a decent job of IMITATING east coast pizza. It doesn't quite get there though. Stll, a great place to sit outside and grab a pizza before a Giants game.
author: Matt N.

description:
Food is OK, pizza is very well cooked and delicious.  How the hell can you put a 4" pizza in front of another member of our species and charge them $12.50 for it.  It can't even cost you over a dollar after labor costs built in? 

Incredibly over priced.  Convenient location, but other pizza places are right on 3rd.  Out of principal - don't eat here.  They are ripping you off!  And your drivers are like evil sewer dwellers from Mad Max where do you find these zombies?
author: Michael R.

description: We come here for take out.  My husband recently had the siciliano, thin crust and really liked it.  It's certainly not the cheapest, $24 for a medium- but I think it's worth it.
author: Lizete S.

description: I know this place is a chain but i was so impressed! I grew up in New York and can be such a pizza snob, but i actually thought this pizza was quite delicious!  we got the margarita to share and also a bowl of minestrone soup.  both were delicious, though i thought the pizza was pretty overpriced.
author: Lisa C.

description:
New Yorker born and raised and I have to say their margherita pizza is fantastic.  everything else is tasty but not nearly as good.

the pasta on the other hand....i can handle the price to quality ratio of the pizza - considering location - but the pasta is NOT worth even close to what they charge.  Never eating that CRAP again....yes...it is CRAP
author: Sean M.

description: Went here for lunch with fellow Jersey natives. I was warned that I'd be disappointed if I was thinking of comparing it to pizza back home. I was surprised to find that it was quite good. The meatball parm is nothing to rave about but go for the pizza. Get it extra thin crust, margherita, with some fresh garlic - while it won't hold a candle to Grimaldi's in Brooklyn or Lombardi's - it will rival many of the pizzerias you find in NY metro region.
author: Bern H.

description: I love thin crust pizza and this place is great for work lunches.  It's thin, it's crunchy and the toppings are good.  Plus they have this awesome panzanella salad that is so simple but to die for. I'm happy to have Amici's just a block from my work.  Always good in a pinch!
author: OakMama D.

description: The pizza is not very good - especially since I just came from the East Coast.  The pasta was better but very overpriced for what you get.  Overall, not the worst place ever, but I would certainly choose other spots over this one.  Its proximity to the ball park is nice, though.
author: B. Y.

description: Nice thin crust pizza and a good variety of topping options.  Delivery was quick.  A little pricey, but not unreasonable.
author: Andi T.

description: We were just looking for a quick bite from a place that delivers, and this pizza was decent.  The delivery was pretty fast.  We got the margherita with tomato sauce with a light crust.  The light crust is almost a must as even with it the bottom was charred pretty good.  You pretty much have to eat this right when you get it unless of course you want a good jaw workout as after about 30 mins the crust requires quite a bit of chewing.  It should be noted I prefer my pizza slightly thicker.
author: Jason P.

description:
What'd I do during Pizza lazy days out? I always order Amicis!!
Very thin pizza & nicely done. I love the margherita & Boston Pizza
DELICIOUSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS.................................
The price is reasonable because the taste is DELICIOUS......................................
author: Ms C.

description:
Pretty much the closest thing you'll find to NY pizza out here. Thin, crunchy crust baked in a wood oven. The toppings and price can get crappily CA, but you can just stick with plain cheese and a barely sub $20 pie. 

Worth the call for delivery or trip to eat in.
author: AnonE M.

description:
I've been here five or six times because it's in the neighborhood. Perhaps I don't dress well enough or don't look cool enough or whatever, but the waitstaff is consistently from average to downright terrible. The management's even worse.

Case in point - last night it took em' 45 minutes to bring me a side salad and bread sticks. I am sure the waitress simply forgot. 

The way the manager barked at me for trying to pay up front instead of paying the waitress. Would have loved to pay the waitress but she was nowhere to be found.

The prices are sort of high for what you get. Add to that poor service and there's no chance - not one - that I'll be back.

Go one mile downtown to any of the Italian or pizza places and you'll do better.
author: Scott B.

description: Not as good as Arinell, but authentic enough for transplants longing for East Coast thin crust.  Plus they've got soy cheese, and fresh garlic is a free topping.
author: Doctor L.

description: Great pizza; crappy delivery service. Waiter.com sucks (minimum charges the force the purchase of a large pizza, exorbitant fees, poorly designed web site).
author: Joe C.

description: Pizza is middle-of-the-road here.  Decor is nothing to write home about.  This place survives because it is one of only a few options before a Giants game. They need to offer cocktails in addition to beer and wine.
author: Matthew B.

description: Man, she sure did love this pizza...  Maybe it was because she's Japanese, with Japanese tastes, or maybe because she was one of those women who just can't taste salt...  But I can.  Ack.  The pizza itself is alright, but after a few slices, you really begin to want a drink.  It's the cheese, it's the bread, who knows what it is, but I taste salt, salt, salt.  Somehow getting the "light crust" option is a little better, so maybe it has something to do with the bricks in the oven rubbing silicon dust over the baking pie?  I can't explain it.  The price, too, has much to be desired.  It's a nice break from the usual routine of the thicker crust west-coast cousins, but it's not something I can deal with very often.
author: Mason G.

description: my favorite pizza place great food friendly staff food gets served pretty fast and its only across the street from the ballpark witch is nice.
author: Matt N.

description: Horrid pizza- chewy dough, extraordinarily salty cheese, I'm convinced the pepperoni was not real meat and the mushrooms looked like they came out of a can. I have yet to bring myself to try the caesar salad I ordered. Way overpriced as well. What a let down.
author: Vanessa N.

description: So if you're trying to arrange lunch between someone Muni-bound and someone Caltrain-bound, 4th & King is the obvious choice.  But despite being abuzz with new construction and speculation, there's actually very few good spots to eat within walking distance.  Amici's, however, saves the day.  I loved it in Mountain View, and even after extensive touring on the SF pizza circuit, Amici's still pulls its weight.  And it's a local (ie, merit-driven), not national (ie, marketing-driven) chain, so don't worry.  This location has that new-building blandness, which is too bad, but the weather usually allows you to sit outside.  Pizza crust is of the thin-but-chewy variety (I guess that makes it East Coast?  I wouldn't know because I'm WEST COAST FOR LIFE, biatch), delicious but it means the pizzas are not as filling as they appear, and thus pricier per portion than other spots.
author: Wes M.

description: Amici's is just overpriced for the okay food they serve.  The company I work for has ordered amici's a of couple times and i think the food is just alright.  In my opinion you're better of going to a New York PIzza or Mountain Mikes Pizza, shoot, maybe even Round Table Pizza.  Although the service was fine and dandy, the food is just way overpriced for the okay food.
author: Chris L.

description: standard good pizza...can't really complain....good pizza...but, nothing fancy....and they deliver.....it's saltier than most pizzas (in my opinion)...but...i like salty.....you can't really go wrong with a amici pizza.....anchovies on the side~!!...brocoli drizzled in olive oil with squeeze of lemons...creamy rich pasta...the clam pasta is pretty creamy rich and just thick good....
author: Hen A.

description: Pretty good pizza, fast delivery. I've had better, but all in all it's good. For some reason I just wasn't a fan of their sausage pizzas. They are quick to deliver, but only if you make a $25 minimum. If you're looking for one pizza and some sides, not sure that this is the best place because of the min. Looking for wings? Sorry. How about garlic cheese bread? Nope...
author: The Sock S.

description: I didn't think the pizza was all that great; it resembled the frozen microwavable kind.  And compared to other pizzas I've tried recently, Amici's just doesn't cut it.  We also could've done without all the cheesy cracks from the waiter.  It's obviously busier just before a Giants game, but the wait is totally bearable.  Too bad there aren't more restaurants around the ballpark.
author: Marsha Z.

description: After waiting for the Giants game to start (yes, it took four hours!), we decided to grab a slice of pizza down the road at Amici's.  Besides the fact it was packed and the wait time was pretty lengthy, we stuck it out and was rewarded with awesome pizza and salads.  Sure, the pizza isn't a "real" New York slice, but it was a lot better than ballpark food.  So, if you ever need a good meal before or after the game, take the five minute walk and head over to Amici's.
author: Shannon W.

description:
amicis just delivered at my job. ( cutie pie delivery boy btw) They delivered on time and brought all the items I requested alnog with complimentary bread sticks sinc e i ordered over $100 worth of food.

i just tried the fresh, soft, warm basil breadsticks with ranch dressing. Hot damn!
author: linda l.

description: I can see Amici's from my apartment window and after staring across the street at it for a year and a half I finally had a slice of their pizza.  Either my friend is a really slow walker or Amici's pizza doesn't start off very hot.  She brought over a Manhattan Clam and after reheating it the pizza was actually pretty good.  Only gave it 3 stars since I've only had one experience with this place and they don't give any coupons, what kind of pizza place doesn't offer coupons!
author: Jen C.

description:
My husband and I are East Coast people.  I always liked our pizza back there but then we came to San Francisco and I discovered Amicis.  We loved it so much.  The thin crust, the toppings, the great and friendly service both at King St. and Lombard.
The only down side is that when we go to our L.I. home for the summer we hate the pizza and find it hard to choose a good place to go on Fridays, our usual pizza day!!
author: Marion K.

description: I ate here yesterday after walking around the San Francisco Giants fanfest. We were ravishing and ready for a delicious meal to relinquish our hunger. We ordered a couple of dinner salads and a small pizza to share between the two of us. The portions were perfect for our hunger and it was all delicious. My only issue with the experience was the service. Our iced teas sat empty for nearly 15 minutes and then the server asked us if we were ready for more. Well duh. I would definitely go back, however, before or after a Giants game. :]
author: Alie C.

description: This is a non-pizza review.  I had the linguine puttanesca just because I love anchovies and saying puttanesca outloud.  Got the whole wheat spaghetti and the totality of everything made me not care.  Very salty.  Huge serving.  No bread on the side.  Great the next day, just add fresh chopped tomatoes to stretch out the anchovy-salty-too-much-of-a-good-thing thing.
author: R.G. K.

description: We had some pizza delivered to work the other day.  Boy, was I unimpressed.  Ralph Barbieri I would be disappointed if I were you to be associated with the pizza in these boxes.  There were two pizzas that I sampled one with an assortment of meat and another with pesto and chicken ?  Both looked like they were made the day before and reheated.  It was dry and oily.  Bad day at the pizza parlor?
author: Robert C.

description: This is the only Amicis I've been to and it was quite good.  I had delivery to my office downtown.  Very easy, fast delivery.  I had a Greek salad and a small pizza.  They were both very filling and flavorful, the salad had a lot of different ingredients, which I really loved.  The pizza was quite addictive, by the end of the 12 hour shift, after going back to it every hour or so and having another piece, I had finished it all.  It may be on the more expensive side compared to other pizza places in the area, but the ingredients definitely taste fresh, so you do get what you pay for.  Plus, I bet it would have tasted a whole lot better in the restaurant and not in my office, but I would order again.
author: M R.

description: Decent food though a bit expensive. Great Pesto Linguini. Fun interior with an open kitchen so you can see them toss the pizza. Service was fast. They even have Dr. Pepper (though not diet). Would only go when I have something to do in that area. Not really worth a trip across town.
author: Pierre C.

description: Came here for a date the other night...we placed our order to go and we were paying in part cash and part credit, and for some reason the machine was not accepting it that way, it would only take all cash or all credit.  This was discovered about 15 minutes of trying.  I will say the guys behind the counter were very nice about all of this and provided really good customer service.  The pizza was standard New York style it was good but nothing to write home about.  Kind of on the expensive side for what you get.
author: Denny R.

description: Popped in to grab a quick dinner.  I ordered the mini pizza with pepperoni, mushrooms, and sausage.  The pizza was very good although it could have used more sauce.  The service was punctual and friendly.  Not much more to say that hasn't already been said.
author: Richard R.

description: Oh Amici's...how I want to write you a 4 star review, with your great combination of thin New York Style crust and your substantial, but not overwhelming toppings.  Alas, your pizza doesn't travel well, for its main attribute in the restaurant (thin, crackly crust) quickly vanishes in the steam generated by your cardboard box, leaving just a floppy thin crust unable to support your toppings.  What is a pizza that doesn't taste good for delivery or take out?  I'm afraid you lose one star for that.  And now, the prices!  I went to you for lunch today for a white clam pizza, which is good enough to drag me from my tomato sauce and pepperoni loving ways.  How was I to know that you were going to set me back $11 for a 7" mini pizza?  Say arrivaderci to another star, leaving you with only two, which are two fewer than you have the potential for.
author: Mike B.

description: OK, Amici's, I love you.  I'd be giving you five stars right now, except you seriously wounded my favorite pizza, the Asante, when you switched vegetarian cheeses.  I don't know why you changed.  Maybe you thought the new "cheese" was more cheese-like.  The old one was BETTER, though.  If the goal is to simulate another item as closely as possible, then maybe the new cheese is better, but if the goal is EXCELLENT food, then the old one was WAY BETTER.  Please consider switching back!
author: R F.

description: I'm a big fan, namely because I appreciate the crust. It never seems too crowded or busy to stop into except before/during/after Giants games. There are other locations around San Francisco, but this is my favorite because it's easier to get to, and parking isn't that much of a yatch if you go during off times like I do.
author: Charlene L.

description: It's the opposite of chicago pizza's!  Thin crust, super greasy, and a tad high on sodium.   I particularly like this location because their servers are very courteous.  It's also conveniently near my place whenever I get the urge for a NY pizza.
author: Jeff H.

description: HATE the DECOR. did i say hate? so much i never want go in there and sit down. now. I'm a big fan of the thin crust, but the pizza is way too greasy. more grease than toppings. turn DOWN the freakin' oven. geez. crust always burnt. gotta respect the crust. treat it right! ok now that i got that off my chest, i do recommend the salads. very yummy new spinach variety. antipasti salad good. tuna salad served in a tomato. good. if anything, eat outside.
author: a w.

description: I'm so glad there's a quality Italian restaurant with reliable delivery like Amici's. They have a nice variety of pasta dishes (not the biggest pizza fan) and you can even get low-carb pasta and salad dressing. I've never waited longer than 1/2 hour for delivery.
author: A. M.

description: Wow, I just had the worst CS phone experience with Amicis and of course, I am running to Yelp to report it. :/ I placed an order over waiter.com for our office lunch and realized after placing the order that it had accepted an old credit card on file and that it was expired.  Thinking this might mess the order up, I called Amicis and was placed on hold.  I am HOPING that this rude service had to do with the fact that they were busy and the phone lines were ringing, but all I wanted to know was that the credit card info was sorted out and that our order would be delivered as scheduled.  The person on the other end was extremely short with me and really impatient, as if trying to get me off the phone.  I understand timeliness and the business of a lunch hour *which is why I ordered at 10:45 am for a larger lunch order AND i've worked at a pizza place (both in the store and delivering pizza)* but I was appalled that he just kept cutting me off and treating the issue as not important -- hey don't you want to get paid for 6 large pizzas? That's it. Be a little nicer to your customers, plz. It's the little things that get people coming back to you.  Now I feel like an ass because I don't want to give a nice big tip to the driver, even though it's not his/her fault at all...it's yours order-taker-guy.
author: Courtney M.

description: I literally just ate the cheese & pesto ravioli and had to throw it away b/c of the taste of the cheese.  I wish i could only have given the food 1 star, but the hostess was very nice.  Way too expensive for lack-luster food.
author: Rebekah H.

description: I really do love Amici's!  Great thin-crispy crust. Excellent customer service and tracking system - they always know your last order! The Greek Isles is a favorite and now the Trentino WITH tomato sauce is excellent. I recommend asking for light cheese all over - reduces the greasiness factor. I have to eat Amici's once a week - ok well I have to balance that out with Delfina Pizzeria now - but it's so good.
author: Mariangela S.

description: Average italian-style pizzas. We had a Margerita with peperoni. Good crust and friendly service, but nothing extraordinary. I think it's a bit on the expensive side, considering what it is. A medium pizza and two sodas ended up $35 with tips and tax.
author: Dennis G.

description: It was hellllllla exxxxpensive ($60 for 2 mediums and a iceberg salad?) but sooooo good.  Eggplant topping and carmelized onions (and feta and some other stuff) was really damn good.  So was the other, whatever it was, cheese and sauce.  Love thin crust and it was good.  How was it $60? Goes good with wine... too good??  $60????
author: Today Y.

description: The pizza is okay, the service is okay, the whole experience was just okay. There is nothing outstanding about the food- if you are a big pizza lover you will be very disappointed. I suppose it is good for ball game grounds to catch a quick bite but other than that, I would not suggest going there.
author: Seema M.

description: I was in the mood for pasta and unfortunately for me, there aren't too many in this area.  I decided to give Amici's a try and noticed their prices were off the charts for a restaurant of its quality, especially for pasta.  I have no problems for shelling out some good dough for good food, but this wasn't one of those cases.   I ordered a small ravioli with a pesto sauce and added some spicy sausages to it.   A grand total of $17.50.   For that price, I got 10 raviolis and 1 1/2 sausage.  Definitely nothing to write home about in terms of flavor, although, certainly not the worse I've had. For nearly the same price, I'd much rather goto a Bambinos or an establishment that is more trendy.
author: Milton W.

description:
foods ok. 

The garden salad is a $7 head of lettuce.

whatever.
author: Ryan P.

description:
this place is expensive for pizza.

i like the that they have a brick oven, but that's about it.

they do brisk business, so my low review won't hurt them. personally, i like domino's and pizza hut better than this stuff. and they also sell thin crust pizzas. but hey, i'm a plumber, so what do i know...

for those of you saying that it's close to ny style pizza, i call bullshit. i fold it every which way and it doesn't have the oil flavor and droopy cheesiness. it's pizza and it's expensive. good news? if you're local, that's the only pizza joint around.

rating: two propane torches
author: dave tastic fantasmo x.

description:
I suppose five stars is a bit high, but to be honest i think their food is fantastic.

The pizza is fresh and very tasty, the garlic breadsticks complement the ranch dressing perfectly, and the eggplant parmesan is probably one of the best sandwiches I have ever tasted.

Excellent service, waiter was smiling and cheerful, and everything seemed very clean (including the bathrooms)

I say you absolutely need to try it, beats a greasy hot dog from the stadium!
author: Fred S.

description:
east coast pizza? i mean i know there is chicago pizza, and new york pizza, but what the heck is east coast pizza?

well if it's what amici's serves up, it's not bad. the specialty pizzas are delicious and perfect for that 2am im-drunk-and-have-the-munchies meal. 

.......but it's not open that late, and they take forever to deliver.

soooooo thats why you order the massive xl pizza at 7, have it show up at 830, and eat half of it during a couple games of beirut/beerpong. then after a long night of drinking in the marina/north beach/mission, you can stumble home, throw 3 slices in the 'wave, and BOOM its pizza and it's good. 

note: expensive. i mean i know its san fran, but you could get pizza for less from extreme. then again, that's extreme pizza. and we all know what that means.....
author: David D.

description: Apparently someone has hacked into my yelp account then felt the liberty to write bad reviews.
author: John F.

description:
Simply the best thin crust pizza I have ever had.

Yes, I have been to New York.  No, I don't think NY has any better pizza than Amicis.

Its a little pricey, but damn, that is one tasty thin crust pizza.  Amicis is the type of place that when you take home a few extra slices you manage to NEVER forget about them in the fridge.  My favorite is the Vegetarian pizza with the garlic topping they offer.  The dark, crispy crust is fantastic.  

The large pizzas are like 3 bucks more than the mediums, go big and savor the flavor for an extra day.
author: Matt R.

description: I'm sorry, but the pizza here is a joke.  The diameter of the pepperonis were as small as Ritz bite size cracker sandwiches.  Actually, maybe they were moreo like buttons.  Additionally, pizza was flat and soggy mcSog. Our company catered from this place twice and each time, every slice I ate was burnt.  I felt like I was eating cancer.  Sorry, Amici's...
author: Mellie P.

description: I love Amici's but it is interesting, the last time I called they told me they will no longer deliver to my house.  Apparently a driver was attacked and pistol-whipped.  I live on Potrero Hill a few blocks away from the housing projects.  The were very apologetic, and offered me a free pizza if I came down and got it myself.  I am just curious how much  of Potrero Hill they have decided to stop delivering to.
author: Troy S.

description: Amici's was alright. We ordered the spicy pepper chicken pizza. I read on their website before we went that they are known for their amazing crispy crust. However, our pizza was slightly soggy. The toppings were really good, but the crust was not so good. I might give them another chance since they are so close to my apartment.
author: Vickie D.

description: Fantastic pizza.  The only reason this restaurant gets 4 stars instead of 5 is the poor wine list.  I mean come on, this is San Francisco and the best wine they have on the list is BV Napa Valley.  You have to be kidding.  However, getting past the wine list the food is very good.  I have eaten at this location many times and had great service and quality food every time.  Most recently, I had the side salad and the Amicis combo pizza.  Great tasting and decent prices.  My most recent visit I had top notch wait service by Anabele.  She was very attentive and not over bothersome.  There are some occasions where the waiter or waitress will not give you enough time to take a bite while continually bothering you.  Anabele was EXCELLENT!  Good food and service often hard to find together anymore.
author: Dion G.

description:
I'm not the biggest pizza fan. Sure it's good, but I guess I've just never felt the deep love that so many people seem to have for it. I was all for trying Amici's though, a stylish little pizza joint in walking distance from work. A neighborhood pizza place snazzy enough to take guests out to, but not so overpriced that you break the bank. The menu ranges from salads to pizzas to other pasta dishes. It appears to be accommodating to nearly every dietary concern imaginable with soy cheese vegan options, tomato sauce-free choices, and even low-carb pizza crust. Our group ordered the vegetarian pizza and salad to share. The salad was fairly tasty--big chunks of tomatoes, cucumber and romaine. Pizza-wise the sauce was fairly flavorful and the crust couldn't seem to decide if it wanted to be a crispy thin crust or a crusty thick crust and settled somewhere in-between. Service was a bit slow, but  I put that aside when the awesome waiter found and returned my bracelet that had slipped off when I removed my jacket.
All in all a pleasant ambiance for enjoying lunch, even if I still don't get the pizza thing.
author: Megan K.

description: I've had New York Pizza before.  Ain't nothing New York about this.  Wrong coast CPK2.  Over priced with mediocre service.  Only reason you should stop here to eat is if you are moving to/from the Beacon, and you need to feed a pack of wild friend-imals.  Or b/c Safeway ran out of Digiornos.
author: Sy K.

description: Had a gift certificate to this Amici's. Ordered pizza- was ready quick and the pizza was actually GREAT!
author: Art A.

description: First decent pizzzzzzza I've had in San Francisco.  The Fonzi L. - brilliant reviewer - hit it right on the $$ -- it is New Haven pizza!  Yum, yum, yum!!!  Also, excellent salads -- like the spinach salad with feta, pinenuts, homemade vinegarette...  A little bit pricey but you can't compare the price of a decent pizza to the cardboard available elsewhere.
author: Cara C.

description:
hey asshole pizza delivery driver in a marron saturn!

who the hell was your driving instructor, ray charles? do you even know what a blinker is ya douche bag? 

suck it!
author: Dr. L.

description:
day-um, i love this pizza.  reminds me of italy or ny, thin and tasty!

super thin crust and all the right spices with great, fresh toppings.

i also am a sucker for the salads which are huge and very fresh.

one star off since they won't deliver to my house (twin peaks).  bastards.
author: Tony A.

description: I had our pizza delivered. It was cold and greasy. The crust was lifeless and way to thin for my liking. Perhaps dining in would be a better option, but with Extreme Pizza in the neighborhood, there is no need to suffer from inferior pizza syndrome!
author: Darrin D.

description: Amici's is ok, unless you want a mushroom and sausage pizza which they make abysmally.  They also have a very limited menu outside of pizza.  Their salad was pretty good.
author: Courtney Y.

description: I'm giving this Amicis outlet a probationary "4" since the Pizza was donated and I didn't have to pay.  It had sat around for a while and cooled off but I will say that the crust and topping seemed to be authentic (and yes I am dissing those yelpers who said it was tasteless).  I do know authentic Neapolitan Pizza.  They donated several different varieties and I tried to sample them all.  Kudos to Amicis for trying to be close to genuine.  Whether  they "pass" probation and move on to a permanent "4" remains to be seen.  I need to sample it hot and fresh.  From my perspective Amicis seems to be one of the few places in San Francisco that has genuine Neapolitan (aka East Coast style) pizza.
author: Robert H.

description: I love the linguine with red clam sauce.  Typical I know, but it always hits the spot! Better than the pizza imo
author: Joe O.

description: Their pizza isn't bad - not great, but for someplace that delivers it passes. Service sucks - I called for delivery over the summer when we couldn't leave the house. The pizza never came. An hour later, the manager told me (she had taken the order) that she had entered it as a pick-up. I tried to get her to knock some of the price off the pizza, but she wouldn't budge. I paid for the pizza, when it finally did arrive, but vowed to never solicit them again.
author: Holly B.

description:
Amici's and I have an openly love/hate relationship. 

Why? you ask... 

Well, it's not consistent, sometimes you go in and the pizza is great, the service is great and other times it isn't. Now when the pizza isn't rushed and it's cooked to perfection it's really good, but when it's done half assed and they are rushing, it's awful. I go back to places because I want that specific something..... and usually with chains, that specific something always should taste the same....... and when it doesn't come out like it should, you get disappointed. That explains my relationship with Amici's hopefully one day it'll be strictly love, for now... it is what it is.
author: S A.

description:
I was so excited for Amici's, but walked into a nightmare. The hostess didn't even smile. She looked more irritated than anything. Maybe it was because I was standing there for a long time waiting for her to acknowledge me. It wasn't busy I swear. But it took them 20 minutes to seat my party of 5. We got there, the waiter like threw the menus down, didn't even ask how we were doing. Took our orders...and was off. I'm not a picky customer, really I'm not. Usually, when people act grumpy I try to make an excuse for them. Like, uhhh they must be having a bad day. Well good gracious...they ALL were having a bad day! NO one checked up on us, no one said thank you, and when we were getting up to leave, the hostess, waiters, and whatever else they are were standing by the door and again...didn't even acknowledge us. I'd hate to think this was some racial problem...but wow. I'm never coming back here again.

The pizza wasn't that great anyway. I'd rather go to Pizza Hut if I want that kind of service again. Thanks!
author: Ang L.

description: My friends and I were looking for a place eat before a Giants game. Unfortunately, Momo's and Pete's Tavern were completely packed, so we decided on Amici's. They had a good crowd going, but definitely not packed. It was mostly populated by families. I guess this is more of a quiet family spot before a game. We ordered the Combo, Calabria, and Trentino pizzas. Overall, they were nothing special. I think the taste was there, and good fresh ingredients. But I'm more of a deep-dish pizza girl. Most likely not going back because there are better and more affordable places to eat at around the ballpark. Now I know that I must leave work earlier next time, so I can get to Pete's earlier and get a spot. I'd much rather spend money on a burger and beer.
author: Wendy L.

description: honesty I do not know what all the fuss is about with this place.Only reason I gave it 3 stars was for the awesome server(female) but as far as the food goes it so so at best.Not a lover of the thin crust pizza but even the pastas I have had are not that good IMO !Good beer and great location right across from the ballpark.Food is also overpriced for the what you get even in the bay area.
author: Joe P.

description: Ordinary and expensive. This corporate chain uses a pre-mixed, bagged commercial flour that is neither organic nor chemical free. Ask them to show you the label on the bag it comes in. Really weak beer and wine list. In a city with places like Tommasso's, Delfina, and A-16 why pay more for mediocrity.
author: David J.

description: Pizza is great, I am a big fan of thin crust and this is a great spot.  A little pricey but after a slice very much well worth it.  Usually only take out for me and the ladies at the register have always been friendly a must eat spot.
author: Ashwin G.

description: So I stopped in here during the giants game last night, because I figured it wouldn't be crowded about 45 minutes into the game. I was right. This allowed us to be seated quickly and take our time, so we ordered their hearth-baked breadsticks. They were hot from the hearth (I practically burned my thumb on them, cause it got stuck inside the breadstick...) and came with tasty ranch and marinara dipping sauces. I ordered the linguini with pesto and clams and enjoyed every bite. The clams had a little sand in them....but that's normal. Overall, a good place for pizza or pasta, but the menu lacked much else.
author: Matt H.

description: One time my transplanted NYer coworkers let a California guy convince us to order pizza from a different place for lunch. He no longer works for us. The best pizza this side of Philadelphia, hands down!
author: Suge K.

description:
the pizza sauce tastes like ketchup. ketchup, in case anyone was confused is for fries, NOT pizza.

The only way i end up eating htis is if someone orders delivery, and now instead of pizza, im eating ketchup and cheese. this makes me unhappy.

the pesto passable, hence the 2 stars.
author: Geetika A.

description: Fresh Hot Slices for $4 before a Giants game are a savior.  This is way better than the salty rich pizza they serve inside.  even better than the club level pizza.  This is great if do not have enough time to sit down an order a full pie before game time.  Some of us do have to work you know.  I do not think i have ever bought a box before a game and had it make it to the Willy Mays statue, and its right accross the street.  Its that good.
author: Jimmy M.

description: Good pizza with a thin crust, but not the best I've ever had.  Still better quality than most places outside of NYC!
author: Selene K.

description: I have eaten more pizza in the last month than any other time I can remember.  But it is SO good.  Amici's was right up there with the best.  I had just a plain pepperoni pizza and ate almost the whole thing it was so good.  Fast delivery and worth the price!
author: Bree W.

description: Yum. Yum. Yum-yum. We've had the plain, the Boston (mmm..fried eggplant) and the Philly (caramelized onions, peppers and spicy Italian sausage). All were very delicious. Great crust, good sauce, great, fresh toppings. It's too expensive to be our regular spot but a good treat. Delivery was very fast.
author: Liv B.

description: Save yourself some money - over-priced for a thin, burnt crust of pizza.  Tasted like cardboard with tomato sauce.  Tasted burnt. Had lunch and two of us order 7" pizza ay $8.00 & $12.00 each expecting to be filled - Left hungry for some good pizza.  How can anyone say that this pizza is great.
author: Billy C.

description: My parents really enjoy this restaurant because a) it is convenient location wise (close to freeway access), b) parking is easy for dinner on weekends (if nothing is going on at Pac Bell/AT & T Park), and c) the food is pretty good.  We usually share a spinach salad or garden salad and order two large pizzas (Amici combo and "wildcard" choice).  We've tried the manhattan clam & garlic, spicy chicken, and hawaiian (pineapple/canadian bacon aka ham).  In general, the pizzas are good if you enjoy thin crust, but they sometimes overcook it especially the combo.  Tried their lasagna which is not bad.  Also, brought out-of-town relatives here for a family dinner (party of 12) when Tommaso's was closed for vacation.  The vibe is of a chain restaurant, but the classic sport photos lend a warmer feel.  The original on 3rd Avenue in San Mateo has less of a "chain" feel.  Add a half star for the waiter who constantly asked us if we wanted soda, ice tea, and/or ice water refills.
author: Mike C.

description: I was surprised to see so many bad reviews for this place. I enjoyed our lunch and thought it was the closest I could get to my favorite pizza joint in NYC. After falling in line and gaining possession of our own World Championship replica trophy prior to the baseball game, we walked over to Amici's for lunch. While the sight of my own palm sized Giant's trophy was a huge disappointment, lunch at Amici's quickly lifted my spirits. The thin, crisp crust and fresh basil atop our mushroom and salami pizza was satisfying.  It wasn't piled with an overwhelming amount of toppings or cheese. Service was quick despite the ball game crowd and the wait surprisingly not long at all.
author: Yelp O.

description: The only pizza I've enjoyed from Amici's is the margherita but sometimes the crust tastes like cardboard.  I live upstairs so I've been able to notice the inconsistencies.
author: Elena S.

description: Amici's is an awesome place to eat before or after a Giants home game. Beware of crowds during game days and nights. Delicious thin crust pizza and warm atmosphere. Make sure to ask for extra garlic on the side... then buy extra mints.
author: Leroid D.

description: Work was treated to delivery from Amici's the other day.  They delivered fast but we had ordered 20 sodas and they only came with 5.  So the delivery guy had to go back to pick up the rest of the sodas.  He said it would only take him 10 minutes, but it almost took him an hour.  We had the Veggie, Philly, and Combo pizzas.  I only tried the Veggie & Philly, but they were pretty good.  Thin crust, but it was kind of burnt.  The pizzas didn't really LOOK very appetizing either.  But they were good.  Just goes to show that looks can be deceiving.
author: Kris L.

description:
extra 5% charge to your bill!!!!!!!!!!!!!

idiot place adds 5% to your bill because they're forced to pay their workers what they should.
author: V M.

description: OK, it's late Saturday afternoon and the Michigan football game comes on at 5PM. I'm in a hurry, trying to order a pizza, grab some drinks from the grocery store nearby, and get home before my guests arrive.  I order the Trentino (knowing one guest won't eat sausage) and they tell me it will be ten minutes.  So, I take a seat and wait.  About ten minutes later, I look down at the receipt in my hand, and lo and behold, it says pizza Siciliano instead of Trentino! Oh, no!  I brought my receipt over to the host who took my order and told him I ordered the Trentino pie.  He said he made a mistake and looked embarrassed.  At that point, I said don't worry about it, 'cause the pie is about ready to come out and I'm running late.  (Hmmm...how rude is it to ask a guest to pick the sausage off of her pizza?  Oh, well.)  The manager came over and checked with me, and I said no worries, I'll take the Siciliano.  He said he'd check w/ the kitchen, then told me the pizza was almost done.  I waited a little bit longer, then the manager came out w/ TWO pizzas.  He said he felt bad about the mix-up, and had the kitchen make a Trentino to go along with the Siciliano.  I was so surprised and pleased, and, relieved that no one had to pick off the sausage!  Plus, both pizzas were delicious.  Big thanks for the customer service.  That's how it should be done, and made me a loyal customer. Kudos!
author: Suzy S.

description: Good pizza, not too crowded. BUT they have VEGAN CHEESE! So it is a great place to take my vegan friends and watch them create crazy pizza.
author: Alyssa C.

description: Amici's ingredients are fresh and tasty. I'll take thin crust pizza over deep dish any day. Unfortunately, they are cheese-stingy (I recommend ordering them with extra cheese) and the crust tends to be charred.
author: Evelyn B.

description:
personally i'm not a fan of thin-crust pizza, but amici's is pretty good.  they have quite a good variety in their menu, from pastas, pizzas and other dishes.  the place is clean and if you want, you can sit and dine outside as well...
we had the pizza with the artichoke hearts, sun dried tomatos, feta, and we added italian sausage to it... 
reasonabily priced.
author: charlotte s.

description:
tasty fire oven thin crust.  it gets a minus star b/c it is on the pricier side (those little mini pizzas cost even more here than in an airport)
i had the philly--they have a nice menu selection.
author: Rob C.

description: Closest thing I've found to NYC's Grimaldi's pizza on the West coast. The pizza's usually great except for the occasional burnt one, but all in all its the only pizza in San Francisco I'll eat.
author: Valerie G.

description: My second choice for east coast style pizza. This tastes good and is fairly close to the real deal. I prefer Arinell's, but this is what they get at work some times and I am always appreciative.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description: I eat Amici's pizza pretty often (at least twice/month) because it's near me and delivers.  My favorite pizzas are the New York and the New Haven White Clam.  In general, the pizzas are pretty good, but nothing special.  Amici's is pretty comparable to what'd you get at a run-of-the-mill pizza place in NYC.  The pastas that I've had (meat lasagna and penne with meatballs) are pretty mediocre.  Amici's is a little expensive for what it is, but the location is clean and new.  Also, delivery times are pretty quick and the pizza is always piping hot.  If I was able to, I'd probably give it 3.5 stars.
author: Saw T.

description: If I could give negative stars I would. Burnt, no-topping, sad excuse for a pizza. Boo!
author: Alexandra S.

description: This an east coast pizza crust with a Califonia flair. The crust is nice and thin but usually burnt (The Amici's in Redwood Shores is much better than the one in the city). Pepperoni's are small but the sausage is cut into strips like NY. There's other better pizza joints in the city.
author: Keoni U.

description: Two stars for being one of the few restaurants within walking distance of my place, but don't bother with their pasta- I can make it better at home with bottled sauce. Pizza usually comes burnt on the bottom. Booo.
author: Erin A.

description: Its oookkkk.... nothing to get really excited about.  the crust was a little soggy in the center and over all the crust was not chewy enough.  We got half clam and half amici's combo.  the amici's combo side was a bit on the oily and salty side, even for pizza's standard.  Dont think i will go back there anytime soon.
author: Janet S.

description: Amici's has great pizza. I really like it. I've only been there one time, but hey, that's because I'm not down at their neck of the woods all the time. They are a little pricey, but I think it's worth it. The pizza was really good, and their bread sticks are the best I've had in a while, and the waiter we had was really efficient and pleasant. Also, they have a "bar" area you can sit at, and watch the guys make pizza. I thought that was pretty cool.
author: Danielle S.

description: Where to begin??? First off, I love the location. After a pizza for dinner, it's fun to walk over to the ball park. Plenty of room outside for a big party, or inside for an intimate meal. The staff is always friendly and joke with us back (my family is a bunch of jokesters). The pizza is splendid. Besides for my dad's own pizza, this is one of the best in San Francisco. Thin crust is how all pizza should be. They put just the right amount of cheese, and it always tastes fresh. I am Italian, so you know I am picky about Italian food. Amici's is just wonderful. I must point out that I have only had the pizza here. The pizza is there specialty. I would have pasta somewhere else (it may be good here but places that specialize in pizza, usually aren't good at the pasta). The price is not bad either so if you're looking for a step up from fast food pizza, but still in your price range go to Amici's!
author: Giovanna C.

description: Nice quality pizza, and delivers to financial district!  Very flat crust, NY style.
author: Max L.

description: This is for the Marina location: Very average pizza, especially when they burn the bottom, which is too often. The meatball sandwiches are small.  But some of my friends dig the fried eggplant pizza.
author: Max C.

description:
i don't know what it is about this place but i sort of enjoy the pizza when i have it delivered but never when i get it there.  i think it may be that the decor of the place turns off my taste buds.  it makes me feel like i am in one of those chain casual dining places. the lack of a neighborhood feeling in that area of town doesn't really help either. i don't think i would ever eat here but they have vegan cheese and i have a vegan boyfriend so we are doomed to be together.

oh yeah and i hate it when people advertise as new york style pizza and they are soooo not new york style pizza.
author: amanda w.

description: It's the best pizza I've found in the area (so 5 stars based on the curve) though it's definitely NOT New York pizza.  They have a great assortment of good toppings, and its fun getting several smaller pies and trying out different combinations. Major downside - it does not reheat well.  Very busy on game nights.
author: J P.

description: If you like thin crust pizza, you should definitely check this place out. Nice combinations.
author: Beth W.

description: I'm from New York, and this is real New York pizza. Word of caution: I've also had their pizza at their Union Street and San Mateo locations, and it was nowhere near as good, not sure why.
author: David Y.

description: My favorite pizza place in San Francsico!!!  I love the pollo with sauce.  Mmm.. roasted garlic baby!!
author: Bonnie D.

description:
it was pretty good thin pizza considering i'm a thick crust type (like milano's or blondie's -- well that's super thick ).  

had a custom made super yummee fried eggplant, pesto, feta cheese, carmelized onions, garlic & mushroom medium sized pizza ................super yummee again BUT  like mae said HELLLLAAA expensive.......................  2 medium sized pizzas & a salad for $63!!!!!   custom-made made it very expensive:  the eggplant, garlic & pesto alone were $3 toppings EACH, carmelized onions, feta & mushrooms were $2 toppings EACH......was a good experience, but not paying $60 bucks again!!!!!    so 3 stars for such an expensive pizza.....
author: Cindi N.

description: This place is really good.  We come here for dinner just before a game.  The only reason why I gave it three stars is because the portions of pasta are not as big as it is in Redwood Shores.
author: May A.

description: In town from the East Coast, I was thrilled by Amici's!!! Thin crust and made as I requested, you'll want to eat more than your hungry for...it's that good! Only drawback...delivery minimum of $25! :(
author: Marlo G.

description: The did a nice job with the space and the outdoor tables are a bonus. Of course the pizza is decent, although on the pricier side. I actually enjoyed the chicken ceaser salad which wasn't anything fancy (parmesan, chicken, croutons, dressing and lettuce) but they added complimentary anchovies which added a little extra flavor.
author: Nicolas H.

description: Lets all be honest....If your from the east coast, you know the pizza is here is just plain terrible.  I have yet to taste pizza even close to the quality of pizza you can eat in NJ or NY.  But, I will say Amici's is fairly decent and although not comparable to a ny slice, is still at least edible.  Unlike the other pizza places here they at least make the effort to taste edible which is why I gave them 4 stars.  I suggest this place although I don't agree that it is an east coast pizzeria...cost is a bit high as well.
author: christopher h.

description: Definitely not my favorite pizza in the city but it used to be the only pizza place near me so I ate it ALL THE TIME! Fast delivery service and friendly staff. I enjoyed the vegetarian pizza but other than that wouldn't jump at the chance to eat there again..especially with it being out of the way. And they wouldn't let my dog and I sit outside on nice days....big strikeout for me.
author: Stephanie J.

description: The pizza here is to die for.... The pizza is baked in an old fashion open flamed oven. Chewy crust with the freshest ingredients and there marinara sauce is one of its own. If your into the East coast style of pizza I recommend you try Amici's.
author: Carolina H.

description: Gets the job done when you're in the mood for a quick pizza.  Would rate the pizza decent for the price and decor.  The service is sometimes lacking (I do take out from here, and they sometimes forget to give it to me, leaving me unnecessarily waiting for half an hour).  I usually get the manhattan red claim pizza and it's always pretty decent.  Only complaint is that they are literally only a pizzeria and don't have much other Italian food or pasta.
author: Mark P.

description: This place is OVER-RATED to the extreme.  It's not bad pizza, but it is definitely not the best.  Their toppings are cheap and sparse, the crust is practically burnt, and the dumbest move I have seen is that they are 1 block away from the home of the WS Champion SF Giants, and huge advertisers on their flagship radio station (I swear Barbieri has part ownership with the way he drools over this place!) and they don't even have the brains to put a TV up in the place to watch the game if it's sold out, or you're running late, or just want to have a beer and hang out! Get with it, people!
author: Maher S.

description: Good pizza, good pasta, friendly service, and good for groups. Also fun to watch the guys in the kitchen toss the pizza dough.
author: Carly W.

description:
Perfect pizza before a Giants game.

We ordered a large pizza to-go and it was ready in 10 minutes which was surprisingly fast considering how crowded it was!  I forgot what it was called but we got the one with mushrooms, olives, pepperoni and sausage.  I LOVED it.  The crust is thin, but not hard and crunchy.  It had the perfect amount of flavor.  

Its a bit on the expensive side for me but I'll definitely have to treat myself again some time :)
author: S T.

description: There is nothing very attractive about this place. It is just OK. The pizza is OK too. I'm not saying is bad, it is just that I can't find anything that encouraging to say ... maybe other reviewers. I definitively have had better pizza (Cineccita), and worse (Costco).
author: Javi V.

description: Funny - on the East coast we always compare everything to the WEST coast.  Still, I was surprised to find the pizza was very good.  The crust is just the right combination of chewy-crunchy. Toppings were tasty.  Service was excellent.  For the price you can't beat it.
author: Jeffrey O.

description: The pizza is ok - nothing special - just typical thin crust "New York" style pizza.  It won't let you down, but it won't really leave you craving for more.  Oh, and the convenience of delivery is undercut a bit by their prices, but whatever.
author: Omar S.

description:
One advice: Only order pizza's here, the other items on the menu are horrible.  Or maybe the pasta's are prepared 'the American way' (what's with all the cheese on everything?) here and I just don't like it.  That's a possibility too.  ;-)

My husband really likes their pizza, so that's a good thing.  I don't think their pizza is bad, but I don't especially like it either.  It's never crowded (or at least not when we go, so not when there's a game on).
author: Marijke D.

description: Great pizza!  I usually don't like thin crust pizza but Amici's is an exception.  Make sure to request the garlic on top, makes the pizza twice as good.  Parking isn't easy but it is still worth the trip.  If it's baseball season be careful.  If there is a game this place will be moshed!
author: Lauren B.

description: Good thin crust pizza. The reason they do not get 4 stars is that 2x they have messed up our delivery order and they are pretty darm expensive for pizza.
author: Adrienne G.

description:
awesome, gourmet pizzas here that cost too much for your own good, but you still come here 'cause the food is just that good.

the pizzas are perfect AND they have soy cheese. several veggie options. my sis loves the vegetarian pizza, which is awesome. and my mother absolutely loves the pollo pizza, which contains roasted garlic, which i love to steal. SHOINK! 

pastas are good, albeit pricey for the quantity. the primavera one can get a little bland, but the eggplant parmigiana is a piece of heaven that disappears all too quickly.

AND this place has vegetarian minestrone!! it's not the best out of the many minestrones i've tried, but it's a start.
author: Veggie J.

description:
$25.95 for a 15" Amici's combo pizza (pepperoni, sausage, bacon, mushrooms, olives).

Delivery was fast.  I don't have much to say about the pizza itself -- it was edible, the crust was ok, and the sausage sucked.  Unfortunately, sausage is my favorite topping.
author: Matthew M.

description: Forgot about good old Amici's at first. Good pizza. I especially like the Margherita and the Garlic pizzas. Plus, you can add their signature roasted garlic to anything and you have a winner on your hands.
author: Benjamin L.

description: My favorite pizza.  Addictive. I crave it nightly.  The caesar salad dressing (more of an anchovy , garlic and olive oil elixir - not creamy) is wonderful.
author: babsie g.

description: The pizza tastes pretty good, but it is horrendously greasy and expensive. Some co-workers and I ordered a large pizza when we had to work late once and it cost about 25 dollars including delivery charge and tip. They charge the full amount for half toppings, which is annoying. The personal size pizza is so small and expensive it isn't really even an option. I would only go there in a group of people who all want the same kind of pizza.  That being said, it is the second best pizza I've had in the SOMA district (after South Beach Cafe)
author: Jay S.

description: Yes they deliver.  Yes there are places to sit outside.  Yes they have beer  by the pitcher.  I actually like their garlic bread very much.  The meat lasagna here is quite delicious!  Also, the vegetarian pizza is delicioso.  This place is always busy on game days.  The staff here are quite friendly and very nice.  The first time I came here the waitress gave me a free beer!  Love that, though I haven't experienced that since.  Anyhoo, it's a great place to come for a casual meal and a good beer.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Lived in sf for about 2 years, relocated from NYC. Closest to NYC pizza. Love the location ( parking stinks). But having the bookstore next door makes it for a cheap outing for a family of 5. 
These guys remember you and treat you like family every time we come back. We no longer live in the city but often go back on weekends, they always greet us with a smile. 
Showed up one time with 11 people and they got us seated in record time. LOVE THIS PLACE!
author: M.P R.

description: I love me some east coast pizza(not New York Style....but more Boston-ish) and Amicis delivers the closest I have seen.  Plus they are across the street from me, so the pizza gets there in about 15 minutes!  Ask for extra thin and crispy crust to be transported back to Boston without the wicked weather!
author: M B.

description: This is our neighborhood Amici and while we love it they are not as consistently good as the Lombard location.  The Manhattan Red Clam Pizza is very good here and we will still come back for the Margherita Pizza b/c when it's good it's fantastic!
author: Kelli B.

description: I like the flavour, I like that it is cooked in a wood oven and I like the interesting combinations of toppings but my jaw aches after chewing on that crust that turns to rubber after it cools down. Chew some gum to work up to it!
author: Cheryl M.

description:
I grew up on Amici's Pizza and have not found any better substitute in America.  I even prefer to most pizza in Italy.  The Pepperoni is a classic, but not for those with high cholesterol, as there is a good deal of grease.  The Pesto is also a good choice.   The highlight of Amici's pizza its thin crispy crust and light cheese.   It's a great bargain and they deliver too.  If you're looking for something healthy go elsewhere.

Pick up a few slices before a baseball game or concert at SBC park.
author: Ian M.

description:
$26 for a lg? thats a lil steep. no? unless that pizza has gold nuggets  or white truffles in it. 
pizza is pretty good.. but  i will still opt for another place if i weren't so lazy.
author: stephanie w.

description: Came here once before on the way to a show.  Didn't have a great experience but thought we would give it another try.  Unfortunately, this visit did not give us any reason to change our mind.  We stopped by for lunch on the way to see Totem.  Right from the start - everything was disappointing.  The place was nearly empty when we arrived yet they wanted to seat us at a table right by the front door.  We asked to be moved to a different table.  The service was substandard.  The waitress could not answer any of questions regarding the food and couldn't make any suggestions.  She never came by to check on us to see how the food was or to ask for refills.  When the pizza arrived, it was black on the bottom.  I made a comment which the waitress ignored.  Ordinarily we love savoring the crust but because it was burnt it was otherwise inedible.  My son said it was the worse pizza he has had.  We would have sent it back but couldn't afford to wait for another pizza or else we'd miss our show.  Plus, $22.95 for a medium sized pizza is highway robbery.  The thing they have going for it is the location - but that is about it.  Before leaving, I asked if they had any comment cards or if I could speak with the manager.  The hostess told me to make a review on yelp.  Ok - you asked for it so here it is.
author: Will L.

description: This is the best pizza I've eaten in San Francisco.  If you like thin crust, go to Amici's.  However, it is expensive.  Not the best bet for your average beer-drinking, superbowl-watching party.  Great for a night when you're having friends over and are too lazy to cook.
author: Katie M.

description: What more can you ask for when seeking out healthy pizza. Soy cheese and low-carb crust were nice alternatives. But it wasn't very filling, and the crust was too thin even for my tastes. Food is probably closer to two stars, but I'll give them a bonus for at least offering a healthier option.
author: Jason B.

description: The food is good. However, it is completely over priced. I ordered two large pastas and the bill was 31 dollars. 31 Dollars? That is way to much for a place like this.
author: Carlos R.

description:
I'm not a pizza fan but once in awhile I crave so I order Amici.
Good service, fast delivery and good pizza.
Once I moved and my boyfriend took me to eXtreme pizza and they were good so I've been ordering from eXtreme... BIG MISTAKE..... i'll never do that again. BAD SERVICE, BAD SERVICE, EXTREMELY BAD SERVICE.... EXTREME SUCKS!!! 

AMICI ROCKS.......
author: Saehee J.

description: Hmmm, delicious!  I had pepperoni and bacon on a small pizza and loved it, can't wait to go back!  Nice clean restaurant with friendly staff.
author: Joann P.

description: This is not one of the best of their pizzareia in the bay but is okay. the place is nice and if you want to eat outside you can too. Be prepared to wait for a long time if it's busy..... the food is good.. i would come back here again... the service people was really nice and that's a plus with me....
author: Ryan s.

description: Decent pie, excellent delivery!  Absolutely ridiculous prices!!!  $30+ for a large pie???  There is nothing east coast about that.
author: Z. G.

description:
Really wanted to like this place ... I pass it on my way home from work.   But after two visits, time to keep looking.   Expected the crust to be crispy, but it fell limp both times.  

Where can I get really good pizza in SOMA area?
author: David M.

description: I used to like Amici's. They delivered to my house. This is the second time in their history that they have revised their acceptable delivery zone and no longer include our location. Can't imagine how they would cut Potrero Hill out of their SOMA location, but it's bad business for them to do this twice since I've been ordering from them. Lame.
author: Shaka Z.

description: I'm addicted to their linguine w/ white clam sauce and their pizza's are excellent.  Delivery is fast with food that arrives consistently good and hot.  It's a little pricey but with an addiction what are you going to do?
author: Liz M.

description: after a long night of partying, i like to call up amicis and slur my order over the phone to them, and they're always sooooooo nice and patient with me. really good phone service compared to other pizza places! i don't even need to rave about their pizzas.... if you've had one, they speak for themselves. really one of the best pizzas around.
author: Michelle I.

description: My favorite pizza in San Francisco!  I've been to both locations, and both are great.  I love the thin, crispy style crust on these.  I always get the Vegan Asante pizza with Daiya vegan cheese, baby spinach, broccoli, red onions, tomatoes, and fresh basil.  I really love that they offer vegan cheese.  My boyfriend always gets a simple pepperoni pizza.  He's a real pizza connoisseur, and he loves the pizza here.    Service has always been good.  I don't know why this place is averaging only 3 stars--it's definitely a 5 star pizza joint!
author: Paula L.

description: I come to Amici's when I go to my favorite Dentist.  The pizza is quite tasty.  However, their Cesar salad is just o.k. to my mind.  The service is always pretty good.  All in all pretty good place if you are on the go.
author: JULIA L.

description: This place has great pizza I would go here any day I recommend this restaurant everyone who likes New York style pizza also great service everyone is nice there.
author: Isabel G.

description: Amici's offers a gluten free dairy free version of their pizza which is terrific for kids in the autistic community who are on this special diet. I have been a customer for over 10 years. However, I had a  bad experience in the Dublin restaurant (not busy either) where we waited over one hour for my son's $26 pizza (for one person as they won't make smaller pizza's for children as I am told it's not economical for them/) They got it wrong and we waited another 30 minutes. They did not comp us and could not care less we were not satisfied. Terrible customer service.  It's great they do gluten free, but it's expensive and they don't care about their customers experience clearly. Won't be coming back after 10 years.
author: lauren h.

description: amici's is reliable for thin crust pizza, especially for a chain restaurant.  it's nothing spectacular, but it does its job.  the garlic breadsticks are quite tasty and comes w/ a side of ranch.
author: Helen T.

description: I've been here twice for lunch and both times the food (a small pizza) was good, and the service was very good. I had heard amazing things about their pizza, and indeed, it was tasty. However, it was billed as an east coast place, which it doesn't really seem to be. There's no "by the slice" option for lunch, and the pizzas themselves lack any kind of signature taste, like an unusual cheese or sauce blend.. My experience has been that it's well-prepared, thin-crust pizza, served by nice staff. If you are looking for the "holy grail" of pizzas, this might not be it, but you most likely won't be disappointed if you ignore the hype and take this restaurant on its own terms.
author: t t.

description: They no longer deliver to many addresses in the Mission.
author: Alex C.

description: Way to greasy. I feel like drinking a gallon of bleach to cleanse my system after eating their pizza.
author: eric h.

description: We ordered a large New York style pizza with fresh garlic. The crust was pretty burnt, but it was okay. The service was terrible.
author: Jody G.

description: What!  Only three stars on average??  If you miss NYC pizza like I do, this is the place to go.  I have been searching for a thin crust pizza that is not cardboard and I've found it.  My only complaint is that I wish is were closer to where I live.  I live in Little-Star-land, which, excuse my east coast snobbery, isn't really pizza.
author: Julia O.

description:
I don't really like Amici's pizza because I'm not a fan of thin crust pizza, but it's the only place I know that will deliver quickly (usually within 30 mins) and is open on Saturday afternoons.  In terms of the food, i usually get one of the pizzas because i've found the pastas to be pretty bad and would only give it 2 stars.  HOWEVER, today, i was blown away by their service, which is why i'm giving them 4 stars.  it is cold and rainy and i'm assuming there are tons of people calling in for deliveries.  this time, the delivery took longer than normal, around 40 minutes.  i wasn't too disturbed because I wasn't starving, but it was great to have the delivery guy apologize right away and say that this normally doesn't happen but the bad weather and the large calls for deliveries has pushed them behind schedule.  to me, 10 minutes isn't that much of a delay compared to other pizza places.  when i opened up the box, i found that it was the wrong pizza.  i was slightly annoyed, but the pizza i received looked pretty good, so i didn't call them to complain.  within 20-30 minutes of the delivery, amici's calls me back to ask if i received the wrong pizza and apologized.  they knew exactly what pizza i received (show's there some semblance of logistics) and apologized profusely.  they offered to send me another pizza right away or to credit me for my next purchase.  i chose to accept the credit since i had already eaten and was full.

at the end of the day, i respect amici's more for owning up to their mistakes and preemptively calling me to offer a solution.  even though the food is so-so, it is very likely that i'll order again from them because of this positive experience.
author: Jay M.

description: Being that I live in a semi-new apartment complex and have had serious difficulty getting restaurants to agree to deliver here (because they can't find my street on a map), I was willing to try Amici's as I had seen their delivery car around my apartment previously. My fiance and I didn't particularly want pizza, so we settled on pasta, which was too expensive in our opinion... but when you're a student and it's finals, you do what you have to do. We ordered pesto pasta with chicken. When we got it, they messed up the order... we got alfredo pasta with chicken. Although we were upset, we do like alfredo sauce and opted to just eat the pasta instead of wait for them to come back and fix the order. That was our biggest mistake. About three hours later we were both up with food poisoning, and remained up for the better part of the night. I guess there was something wrong with the alfredo sauce. Whatever the reason, it was a very unpleasant night. Be wary of Amici's... I know I have not eaten there since, and have no plans to--ever--in the future.
author: Bridgette A.

description: I feel so much better after reading some of the reviews about Amici that you cant always trust a consensus. You need someone to trust, and with pizza, I am your man.  If you do not give Amici's 5 starts out of 5, you dont know pizza.  Being from NJ, and thus an expert on pizza, this is up there with Joes in Union, NJ on Vauxhall Road. The only bias is I dont enjoy chicago pizza, the same way. Whenever, guest  visit our winery from Chicago, I always let them know east coast pizza is real pizza. A pizza should be thin and crispy and yes oily!  I wish there was an Amici's in santa rosa. The only complaint I could possibly have is their wine list should be better. Americans have not accepted pizza and wine even amongst those who drink wine. I have the marketing study. Wine is a great  compliment to pizza capache?!
author: Andrew K.

description: Service was quite good last night so I'm bumping what I thought was a 3-star pizza to 4 stars.  I still think Gaspare's provides better value for the money.
author: Mel B.

description: veg. pizza is good. everything else. avoid it. and really avoid it like the plague
author: Derek Alistair J.
